page.title: Factorum ac dictorum memorabilium libri IX

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:Permalink/772743896#Future of magic links|local RfC]] and [[:mw:Requests for comment/Future of magic links|MediaWiki RfC]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Dictorum Factorumque Memorabilium Libri IX.jpg|thumb|1830 version of ''Facta et dicta memorabilia'']] '''''Factorum ac dictorum memorabilium libri IX''''' ("nine books of memorable deeds and sayings", also known as ''De factis dictisque memorabilibus'' or ''Facta et dicta memorabilia'') by [[Valerius Maximus]] (c. 20 BCE – c. CE 50) was written around CE 30 or 31.<ref name="pagexiii">Walker, p. xiii</ref><ref name="columbia">[http://www.bartleby.com/65/va/Valerius.html ''The Columbia Encyclopedia'', Sixth Edition (2001-07), s.v. "Valerius Maximus"]</ref> It is a collection of approximately a thousand short stories that Valerius wrote during the reign of [[Tiberius]] (42 BCE – CE 37).<ref name="pagexiii"/> The stories are a variety of anecdotes illustrating how the [[Ancient Rome|ancient Romans]] lived.<ref name="columbia"/> While the majority of the stories are of Roman life, he does have some foreign stories at the end of some chapters. Most of these are of [[Ancient Greece|Greek life]] and most of those are about [[Greek philosophy|Greek philosophers]] or famous kings.<ref>Walker, p. xix</ref>
Several of the stories relate to moral subjects that parallel those in the [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]]. Valerius refers to his moral stories as "examples" that were to be used as moral guidance.<ref name="pagexxii"/> Valerius' work on the preservation of moral values of the [[Roman Republic]] of the past was widely popular through the [[Age of Enlightenment]], a literary life-span of some 1,700 years. People read Valerius' work for practical guidance in their everyday tasks for living a moral life.<ref name="pagexxii">Walker, p. xxii</ref> This work was especially used as a reference by writers and professional [[Public speaking|orators]].<ref name="pagexiii"/><ref name="columbia"/>
It is estimated that Valerius's work on these nine books took over a decade.<ref name="rarely"/> He obtained material from [[Cicero]], and from [[Livy]], [[Sallust]], [[Gnaeus Pompeius Trogus|Pompeius Trogus]], [[Marcus Terentius Varro]] and other ancient historians.<ref name="rarely"/> Each of the nine books has several chapters. Each chapter is outlined and grouped [[theme (literature)|thematically]] and contains several stories illustrating that theme.<ref name="rarely"/><ref name="table">Walker, p. vii '''Table of Contents'''</ref> This work is the earliest known use of a [[hierarchical organization]] system for topics of a book.<ref>Princeton University Press article ''[http://press.princeton.edu/chapters/s8216.html A short history of information retrieval]''</ref> There are a total of 91 chapters covering a wide variety of subjects drawn from Roman life.<ref name="table"/> Valerius arranges his chapters focused on particular [[virtue]]s, moral and immoral habits, religious practices, superstitions and ancient traditions.<ref name="table"/> There is a thematic guide at the end of the work.<ref>Walker, p. 355</ref>
==Subjects==
===Omens=== One example of Valerius' balanced subject themes covered is where he writes stories about [[omen]]s.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> He notes that the observations of omens had a connection to [[religion in ancient Rome]] since many people of that time believed that omens were from divine providence.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> Valerius records that omens had played an important role when Rome had been demolished by the [[Gauls]] in 390 BCE. The [[Roman Senate|Senate]] was debating whether they should then move Rome to [[Veii]] or rebuild the city walls.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> While they were deciding some [[Cohort (military unit)|cohort]]s had just returned from guard duty.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> Their [[centurion]] then just happened to shout in the assembly place, "Standard-bearer, set up the standard; this is the best place for us to stay." The city was rebuilt in the same place then, since they interpreted these words as an omen.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref>
===Auspices=== One of the subject themes that Valerius wrote about was the [[superstition]] of [[auspices]] in Book 1 Chapter 4.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> Auspices means "bird observations." It is from the [[Latin]] words of ''avis'' (bird) and ''spicere'' (to sight or watch).<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> Before doing anything of great importance, the Romans would "take the auspices" in order to determine what the [[Roman mythology|gods]] approved.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> This was an examination of the behavior of birds in flight or eating.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> It was interpreted by an [[augur]] as to the will of the gods from this behavior.
A Roman story that Valerius writes about is the founding of Rome by [[Romulus and Remus]].<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> He records that the founding of the city was based on the auspices. Remus was the first to "take the auspices" by seeing six [[vulture]]s.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref> Romulus later however saw twelve vultures. Romulus claimed he had a stronger claim because he saw a larger quantity, even though Remus was the first to spot vultures.<ref name="super1">Walker, p. 14</ref>
Another "foreign" story Valerius writes on this theme for a comparison is on the founding of the city of [[Alexandria]] in [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]].<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> It was founded by [[Alexander the Great]] in 331 BCE. The [[architect]] was [[Deinocrates]].<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> He records that when Deinocrates was going to design a great city in Egypt, he had no chalk to use for writing.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> Instead he used a large quantity of [[barley]], and drew out the plans on the ground.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> A group of birds then came from a nearby lake and ate the barley.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref> The Egyptian augur interpreted this to mean that there would be plenty of food for a large city there.<ref name="super2">Walker, p. 17</ref>
===Modesty=== [[File:Marco Porcio Caton Major.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Cato the Elder]]]] Valerius writes on the theme of [[modesty]] in Book 4 Chapter 5 about the fact that there was no separate seating for the Conscript Fathers (Roman Senators) at the theater.<ref name="modesty1">Walker, p. 142, Book 4 Chapter 5.1 reads, ''From the foundation of our city to the consulship of Scipio Africanus and Tiberius Longus there was no separate seating for the Senate and the people when they watched the games. In spite of this, no member of the plebs ever brought himself to sit in front of the Conscript Fathers at the theater; the respect shown in our state was so scrupulous.''</ref> This was from the beginnings of Rome in the 8th century BCE until the time of the consulship of [[Scipio Africanus]] and [[Tiberius Sempronius Longus (consul 194 BCE)|Tiberius Sempronius Longus]] in 194 BCE.<ref name="modesty1"/> In spite of this no member of the [[pleb]]s ever sat in front of the Conscript Fathers.<ref name="modesty1"/> Their respect for this tradition was also shown when one day [[Lucius Quinctius Flamininus]] was to stand in the very back of the theater.<ref name="modesty1"/> He was placed there because he had been removed from the Roman Senate by [[Cato the Censor]] and [[Lucius Valerius Flaccus]]. Flamininus already held the office of [[Roman consul|consul]] and was the brother of [[Titus Flamininus]] (consul 192 BCE), who had defeated [[Philip V of Macedon]] in 197 BCE.<ref name="modesty1"/> In spite of this he still was forced to go to the back of the theater by Cato the Elder. Out of respect however, the entire audience moved Flamininus to the very front so that nobody was in front of him.<ref name="modesty1"/>
Valerius illustrates another story of modesty when he writes of [[Gaius Terentius Varro]].<ref name="modesty1"/> Varro devastated the Roman Republic when he started the [[Battle of Cannae]], one of the worst battles of recorded history. His sense of shame would not allow him to accept dictatorship, even though it was offered to him.<ref name="modesty1"/> The people of the Republic attributed the great loss to the anger of the gods. On the inscription under his death mask shows his good character which brought him more honor that most men receive from the dictatorship position itself.<ref name="modesty1"/>
Valerius records another story of modesty where king [[Hiero II of Syracuse]] hears of the disastrous defeat of the Romans at the [[Battle of Lake Trasimene]].<ref name="modesty2">Walker, p. 156</ref> He immediately sends as a gift to Rome 70,000 bushels of wheat, 50,000 bushels of barley, and 240 pounds of gold.<ref name="modesty2"/> So that the gold was accepted and not returned he presented it in the form of a statue of victory. This was so the Roman people would accept it on religious grounds.<ref name="modesty2"/>
===Parenting=== [[File:Halle CorneliaMotherOfTheCracchi.jpg|thumb|left|An 18th-century portrayal of [[Cornelia Africana|Cornelia]] proclaiming "These are my jewels," in reference to [[Gracchi|her sons]]]] Another example of Valerius' themes is where he writes stories about Roman parents and the affection they had toward their children. A story in Book 4 Chapter 4 on ''Poverty'' is about the [[Gracchus|Gracchus brothers]], [[Gaius Gracchus]] and his younger brother [[Tiberius Gracchus]]. The story relates how one day [[Cornelia Africana]], their mother (daughter of Publius Cornelius [[Scipio Africanus]]), was pestered by a lady guest that was showing off her elegant jewellery. Cornelia patiently endured this lady until her sons came home from school. Then, introducing them to this lady, she proclaimed proudly, "These are my jewels."<ref>Walker, p. 138</ref>
Another example in Book 8 Chapter 8 is about the philosopher [[Socrates]]. He writes of him showing an intimate side which did not distract from his stature because, as Valerius puts it, ''no part of wisdom was hidden from him.'' He tells how Socrates one time made a [[hobby horse|hobbyhorse]] out of [[Reed bed|reed]] for his sons. He would then play with the hobbyhorse with them showing Socrates' personal parental side.<ref>Walker, p. 291</ref>
Valerius writes many stories of other Roman fathers which generally are contrary to the stereotypical image of being brutal and harsh.<ref name=pagexv>Walker, p. xv</ref> Some of these examples are in Book 5 Chapter 7 titled ''The Love and Indulgence of Parents towards Their Children.''<ref>Walker, p. 189</ref> He writes that the real fathers are the ones that are benignly permissive and show indulgence.<ref name=pagexv/> He reports with delight that this kind of father could be found in the streets of Rome and that these fathers ''were as gentle as fathers in a comedy.''<ref>Walker, p. 193</ref> He does, however, describe in Book 5 Chapter 8 ''Fathers who were severe with their children'' some all-powerful Roman abusive fathers as being tyrannical [[patriarch]]s killing and murdering others including of their own blood. He clearly reports these that are extremely strict and severe as no longer in the role of being a loving father.<ref>Walker, p. 191</ref>
Valerius writes of [[Lucius Junius Brutus]], who killed his sons for failing in their military duties, ''He left the role of a father so that he could play the part of a [[Roman consul|consul]].''<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/5*.html#8.1 Book 5, Chapter 8.1]</ref> Other examples of these role changes can be found in Book 6. In Chapter 1.5 where Valerius tells the story of [[Quintus Fabius Maximus Eburnus]],<ref name="page19915">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.5, p. 199</ref> Eburnus had carried out the highest public offices with great splendor and finished off his career with much dignity; however, he had his son punished for a chastity that was dubious.<ref name="page19915"/> In Chapter 1.6 Valerius writes about Publius Atilius Philiscus who was abused as a child.<ref name="page19916">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.6, p. 199</ref> When he became an adult, Philiscus became a strict father on chastity.<ref name="page19916"/> Learning of his daughter's premarital sex, he murdered her.<ref name="page19916"/>
===The role of women=== {{See also|Women in Ancient Rome}} [[File:Tizian 094.jpg|thumb|[[Titian]]'s image of the rape of Lucretia]] Valerius writes of Roman women being generally in seclusion.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} He reports in Book 6 on ''Chastity'' the stereotypical woman as being well-behaved and who would rather face death than dishonor. One story is of [[Lucretia]] in Book 6 Chapter 1.1.<ref name="page198">Walker, p. 198</ref> He writes that she was violently forced to have sex with [[Sextus Tarquinius]], the son of King [[Tarquin the Proud]].<ref name="page198"/> Lucretia could not bear the disgrace and committed [[suicide]].<ref name="page198"/> Another example is about [[Hippo, a Greek woman]]. She committed suicide rather than being raped by drunken sailors.<ref>Valerius Maximus [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#ext.1 Book 6. ext. 1].</ref> Valerius even writes in Book 2, Chapter 6.14, of [[suttee]] being an admired practice model for all women to follow in his day.<ref name=pagexv/><ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/2*.html#6.14 Book 2 Chapter 6.14]</ref><ref name="pagexvi"/>
===Homosexuality=== {{See also|Homosexuality in ancient Rome}} Valerius writes about homosexuality, which was an unusual category for that time period of writers.<ref name="pagexvi">Walker, p. xvi</ref> This aspect of private life was kept under wraps.<ref name="pagexvi"/> The only relationship along these lines that was tolerated by law was that between a master and a slave.<ref name="pagexvi"/> Valerius, however, does report on male homosexuality in the [[Roman army]] and the [[upper class]].<ref name="pagexvi"/> He does not report on female homosexuality nor "[[gay women]]" as some writers did at the time.<ref name="pagexvi"/>
===Roman army=== In the stories of the Roman army, Valerius always records high-ranking military personnel taking advantage of their position. In Book 6 Chapter 1.10 Valerius tells the story of Gaius Cornelius.<ref name="page200110">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.10, p. 200</ref><ref name="bk6110">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#1.10 Book 6, Chapter 1.10]</ref> He was rewarded four times by his superiors to be the senior [[centurion]] of his [[Roman legion|legion]].<ref name="page200110"/> However Gaius Pescennius, a ''triumvir capitalis'' (prison manager) in CE 149, had Cornelius thrown in jail and shackled in irons for having sexual relations with a young boy of free birth.<ref name="page200110"/> Cornelius did not deny the charges and was prepared to make a ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#sponsio|sponsio]]'' (legal guarantee).<ref name="bk6110"/> In so doing, Cornelius was making a statement and putting down a sum of money as a guarantee of truth.<ref name="page200110"/> If the guaranteed statement was found to be false, the young boy was to be paid this amount.<ref name="page200110"/> His statement was to say that the boy openly and willingly sold his body for cash.<ref name="page200110"/><ref name="bk6110"/> The [[tribune]]s refused to allow this, since they thought soldiers of the Roman Republic should not make deals in which they could pay for pleasures at home by facing dangers overseas.<ref name="page200110"/> Cornelius spent the rest of his life in prison.<ref name="page200110"/><ref name="bk6110"/>
In Book 6 Chapter 1.11 Valerius tells the story of Marcus Laetorius Mergus.<ref name="page200111">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1.11, p. 200</ref> Cominius and a tribune of the [[pleb]]s summoned Mergus, a high-ranking military career person, before the people because of sexual relations with young men and women outside his marriage. He was prosecuted and sent to prison.<ref name="page200111"/>
In Book 6 Chapter 1.12 Valerius tells the story of [[Chiomara]].<ref name="page202112">Walker, Book 6, Chapter 1. ext. 2, p. 201</ref><ref name="bk6ext2">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#ext.2 Book 6, ext. 2]</ref> Chiomara was the wife of Ortiagon. During the [[Galatian War]] with Rome of 189 BC, [[Gnaeus Manlius Vulso]] was victorious in a campaign against the Galatian Gauls.<ref name="page202112"/> One of his centurions was put in charge of a group of captives including Chiomara. The centurion made sexual advances towards her and she rejected him.<ref name="page202112"/> Under violence and force he raped her. The centurion then offered, to assuage his shame, to ransom her back to her relatives.<ref name="page202112"/> When he received his ransom and was counting the gold pieces, Chiomara secretly indicated to her relatives to murder him and cut off his head.<ref name="bk6ext2"/> She later presented the head of the centurion to her husband.<ref name="page202112"/>
===Political views=== [[File:Lucius Appuleius Saturninus.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Coin of [[Lucius Appuleius Saturninus]]]] The political views of ordinary Romans basically were not written on by most ancient writers.<ref name="rarely">Walker, P. xvii</ref> Valerius, however, did write about the grassroots customs of Rome as a democratic society.<ref name="rarely"/> He points out that the poorer Romans had goals as to where they wanted to ultimately be and in what direction they wanted to go.<ref name="rarely"/>
One example of how political views were looked upon in his days is where he writes a story on [[Sextus Titus]], who kept a picture in his residence of a murdered [[Extremism|radical]] called [[Lucius Appuleius Saturninus]].<ref name="stitus">Walker, p. 271</ref><ref name="bk81damn3">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/8*.html#1.damn.3 Book 8, Chapter 8.1.damn.3]</ref> Titus was popular with the people because of a new land reform law he proposed; however, he was prosecuted and punished just because of the picture and his political views.<ref name="stitus"/><ref name="bk81damn3"/> He writes that the Romans felt a personal loyalty to the memory of these reformers. The tribal assembly of [[plebeian]]s felt that this memory could be led astray if there was an association to a radical.<ref name="rarely"/><ref name="stitus"/><ref name="bk81damn3"/>
Many times there were [[imposter]]s that said they were sons of populist leaders like [[Tiberius]], [[Gaius Marius]], [[Gracchus]], and [[Publius Clodius Pulcher]]. The people of Rome loved them.<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#7.1 Book 9, Chapter 7.1 and 7.2]</ref><ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#15.1 Book 9, Chapter 15. 1 -4]</ref> In fact, he records that one claimed to be the grandson of Gaius Marius and drew a crowd as what [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] himself would obtain.<ref name="rarely"/>
Valerius records the attitudes of the [[aristocracy]] and the contempt to which the [[Working class|lower class]] was subjected by the Roman elite. He demonstrates this with a story about [[Scipio Aemilianus Africanus]]. Scipio one day preached to a group of [[pleb]]s that basically they are nothing other than just a level above being slaves. He tells them they don't even deserve to call Italy their home.<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/6*.html#2.3 Book 6, Chapter 6.2.3]</ref> Valerius shows a similar concept with [[Publius Cornelius Scipio Nasica Serapio]]. The story goes that Nasica treated a poor man with ridicule and contempt because his hands were so rough from manual labor.<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/7*.html#5.2 Book 7 Chapter 5.2]</ref> Valerius writes of still another example where the aristocratic Claudia had hoped for more of the Roman common people to have been finished off in the [[First Punic War]].<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/8*.html#1.damn.4 Book 8, Chapter 1.damn.4]</ref>
[[File:EumenesII.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Coin of [[Eumenes II]]]]
===Generosity=== Valerius gives examples of generosity in Book 5 Chapter 8.<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref> Valerius writes that generosity is given to those that are poor.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> The Latin word for generosity is ''liberalitas''. The god of wine is Liber. The god Liber and the word ''liberalitas'' come from the word ''liber'', meaning "free." Here he tells the story of how, after the Romans captured Asia from King [[Antiochus III the Great]] in 190 BCE, they gave a large portion of it to their ally King [[Eumenes II]] of [[Pergamum]] free as a permanent gift.<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref>
Another example of generosity which Valerius writes about occurs after the Romans had defeated [[Philip V of Macedonia]]. In 196 BCE, the Greeks had the [[Isthmian Games]]. Here [[Titus Quinctius Flamininus]] proclaimed the independence of the Greek states from [[Macedon]]ian rule.<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref> At the games, the stadium was full of people and Titus had the herald make the following proclamation: "The Roman people and Senate, and Titus Quinctius Flamininus, their general, having vanquished the Macedonians and Philip, their king, order that Greece shall be free from foreign garrisons, not subject to tribute, and shall live under her own customs and laws."<ref name="gen1">Walker, p. 155</ref>
===Kindness and compassion=== The themes in Chapter 1 of Book 5 are [[kindness]] and [[compassion]]; Valerius gives several examples based on these concepts.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> He considered these lesser [[virtue]]s than [[generosity]], although companions of it.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> Valerius writes that kindness is shown to those that are in trouble and compassion is for those whose luck has turned against them.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref> He considered generosity to be the one that derived its name from a god, and should receive the most approval of these three.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
One Roman story is where Valerius gives an example of generosity, kindness and compassion. Here he explains that one day the [[Roman Senate]] was offered a large sum of ransom money for the release of 2,743 Carthaginian soldiers and refused it. The Senate released the soldiers to the representatives that had come to get them, and forgave the crimes. The representatives were astonished and even admitted that they themselves would not have been so kind and generous.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
Another Roman story in which Valerius writes about kindness is where king [[Syphax]] of western Numidia died in prison in Tibur (modern day [[Tivoli, Italy]]) in 201 BCE. The Senate gave him a state funeral with a proper burial.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
Another similar Roman story in which Valerius writes about compassion is where the Senate sent a [[quaestor]] to Alba (in [[Latium]]) in 167 BCE. There King [[Perseus]] of [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]] was banished to and had just died there. They wanted to give him honor and provided a state funeral for the king.<ref name="kind1">Walker, p. 157</ref>
[[File:Forum romanum 1880.jpg|thumb|[[Roman Forum]]]]
===Gratitude=== Valerius gives examples of gratitude in Book 5 Chapter 2 as the theme.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> One example is when Valerius writes about how [[Capua]] was being besieged by [[Quintus Fulvius Flaccus]] at the [[first Battle of Capua]]; there were two Campanian women who had kind feelings for Rome. They devoted much of their time and property to its benefit.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> One was Vestia Oppia, a married woman with a family, who labored everyday for the Roman army.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> Another was Cluvia Facula, a prostitute, who supplied food to the Roman [[prisoners of war]].<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref> When Capua was defeated, the Roman Senate gave back their freedom and property and rewarded them. These two momen were even praised at an important Senate meeting in 210 BCE.<ref name="grat1">Walker, p. 165</ref>
Valerius gives another example of gratitude when he writes of [[Quintus Fabius Maximus Verrucosus]] (c. 280 BC – 203 BC), called '''Cunctator''' (''the Delayer'').<ref name="grat2">Walker, p. 166</ref> Fabius died in 203 BCE after being [[Roman consul|consul]] for five terms. Many people of Rome generously gave money to his funeral in gratitude for his leadership.<ref name="grat2">Walker, p. 166</ref> When he was still alive, to show gratitude of his outstanding service to the Roman people, a [[referendum]] of the [[pleb]]s gave equal power to his [[magister equitum]] [[Marcus Minucius Rufus (consul 221 BC)|Marcus Minucius Rufus]] as co-dictator in 217 BCE.<ref name="grat2">Walker, p. 166</ref>
[[File:Carthage location 2.png|thumb|left|[[Carthage]] location]]
===Ingratitude=== Valerius gives as the theme "ingratitude" in Book 4 Chapter 3. Valerius writes that [[Scipio Aemilianus]], grandson of famous general [[Scipio Africanus]], had destroyed two major cities, [[Numantia]] and [[Carthage]], that were major threats to Rome. However, in Rome later, he met his death in mysterious circumstances in 129 BCE.<ref name="myster">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/4*.html#1.12 Book 4, Chapter 1.12]</ref> There was never anyone in the [[Roman Forum]] that avenged his death.<ref name="myster"/>
Valerius writes of another example on ingratitude being the circumstances around [[Publius Cornelius Scipio Nasica Serapio]]. Nasica had led a group of conservative senators of the Roman Senate to kill the populist tribune of the plebs [[Tiberius Gracchus]] in 133 BCE.<ref name="merit">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/3*.html#2.17 Book 3, Chapter 2.17]</ref> He soon afterward had to withdraw from public life because the people of Rome had judged his merits unfairly.<ref name="merit"/> Nasica, a [[Pontifex Maximus]], went to [[Pergamum]] ostensibly as a [[diplomat]] and never returned.<ref name="merit"/> He died there, but never missed his country because the Roman people were so ungrateful for what he considered a great deed he had done for them.<ref name="merit"/>
[[File:Gaius Gracchus Tribune of the People.jpg|thumb|right|The [[rostra]] at the Roman Forum]]
===Infamous crimes=== On another theme, Valerius writes of several examples of infamous crimes in Book 8 Chapter 1 and how they related to [[jealousy]].<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref>
One example Valerius records of acquittal ''(absoluti)'' is where Marcus Horatius is found guilty by King [[Tullus Hostilius]] of killing his sister.<ref name="abs811">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/8*.html#1.abs.1 Book 8 Chapter 1.abs.1]</ref> Horatius was acquitted of the crime when he appealed to the public.<ref name="abs811"/> The brutal nature of the killing influenced King Tullus to convict him; however, the motive for which Horatius did it influenced the people.<ref name="abs811"/> In a battle defending Rome Horatius defeated the Curiatius brothers and killed them. His sister was in love with one of these brothers and planned on marrying him.<ref name="abs811"/> She wept over him, hearing of his death. Horatius murdered her then because of her premature love affair with the enemy.<ref name="abs811"/> The people of Rome felt this was harsh punishment rather than an actual crime of the Roman Republic. Horatius received glory for not only killing the Curiatius brothers, the enemy, but for killing his sister.<ref name="abs811"/> In this case the Roman people were acting as a strict guardian of chastity.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref>
Another case Valerius records is where the Roman people were acting as an unfair, lax judge. In this case [[Servius Sulpicius Galba (consul 144 BC)|Servius Sulpicius Galba]] was being harshly denounced at the [[rostra]] by [[Lucius Scribonius Libo]], tribune of the plebs in 149 BCE.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref> [[Cato the Elder]] supported the tribune's charges in a grand speech at a [[Roman assemblies|Roman assembly]] as is recorded in his ''Origins''.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref> Galba had committed an atrocious [[war crime]] against the [[Lusitanians]]. He had made a peace agreement with the Lusitanians, but then massacred 8,000 of them while he was governor of [[Hispania|Spain]] in 150 BCE.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref> Galba, being a great speaker in his own right, had no real defense for his crimes. Through bribery and bringing forth his children and the orphan child of a relative before the public in a speech for mercy, he procured his acquittal.<ref name="absol2">Walker, p. 266</ref>
Another case where Valerius records ancient history crimes is about Gaius Cosconius, [[praetor]] in 89 BCE and governor of [[Illyria]] from 78 to 76 BCE.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref> He was accused of misgovernment under the [[Servilian Law]] passed in 101 BCE.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref> There was no doubt that he was guilty; however, he recited a poem about his accuser, Valerius Valentinus, and got an acquittal.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref> The poem was about how Valerius seduced a young man in a striped [[toga]] and a young freeborn woman. Valerius was then convicted by the acquittal of Cosconius.<ref name="acquit1">Walker, p. 268</ref>
===Outrageous behavior=== Valerius reports in Book 9 Chapter 5 under Foreign Stories that [[Alexander the Great]] had three stages of arrogance.<ref name="alex">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#5.ext.1 Book 9 Chapter 5.ext.1]</ref> One was that he looked down on his father [[Philip II of Macedon]] and claimed that Jupiter Hammon was his real father.<ref name="alex"/> Another was that he took up the ways of the [[Persian people]] by dressing and behaving their way.<ref name="alex"/> Still another was that Alexander believed himself to be a god, not a human being.<ref name="alex"/>
Valerius writes another foreign story here of [[Xerxes I of Persia]].<ref name="xerxes">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#5.ext.2 Book 9 Chapter 5.ext.2]</ref> To show his outrageous behavior and arrogance, he tells how Xerxes summoned all the leaders of Asia together.<ref name="xerxes"/> Just as he was about to declare war on Greece, he tells them, ''I did not want people to think that I was acting on my own initiative, so I brought you together here. But remember that it is your duty to obey me rather than persuade me.''<ref name="xerxes"/> Valerius reports that in the invasion, Xerxes suffered such a defeat that one would wonder if his words were just arrogance or stupidity.<ref name="xerxes"/>
Valerius writes on still another foreign story of [[Hannibal]] and how arrogant he was after his success at the [[Battle of Cannae]].<ref name="hannibal">[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/9*.html#5.ext.3 Book 9 Chapter 5.ext.3]</ref> He tells how Hannibal had [[delusions of grandeur]] and would not then receive any of his fellow citizens directly. He would only communicate through a go-between.<ref name="hannibal"/> He even insulted his cavalry commander Maharbal, who had said in front of his tent in a loud voice that he had planned things so that Hannibal would be dining on the Capitol in Rome within a few days.<ref name="hannibal"/>
==Other topics== Some other subjects that Valerius wrote about included: *Bravery *Cruelty *Dreams *Fidelity *Friendship *Innate characteristics *Moderation *Modesty *Omens *Parental Love *Physical resemblance *Prestige *Revenge *Superstitious cults *Women lawyers
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References==
===Primary sources=== *Valerius Maximus, ''Factorum ac dictorum memorabilium libri IX'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/1*.html text] *Valerius Maximus, The Latin Library has the Latin text of [http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/valmax.html all the books]
===Secondary sources=== *Walker, Henry John, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5imDC6VN-FcC&pg=PP1&dq=Valerius+Maximus&sig=UFVY_XgijRWDMSYh0zIoFDeXfrA#PPP1,M1 English translation] of Valerius Maximus' ''Memorable Deeds and Sayings: One Thousand Tales from Ancient Rome'', Hackett Publishing (2004), {{ISBN|0-87220-674-2}}
==External links== {{wikisource|la:Factorum_et_dictorum_memorabilium_libri_IX|''Factorum et dictorum memorabilium libri IX''}} * {{cite web | last = Sheridan | first = Paul | title = Selected Anecdotes by Valerius Maximus | publisher = Anecdotes from Antiquity | date = 2015-09-19 | url = http://www.anecdotesfromantiquity.net/selected-anecdotes-by-valerius-maximus/ | accessdate = 2015-09-19 }}

revision.text:
[[File:George Primrose and Lew Dockstader in 1898.jpg|thumb|George Primrose and [[Lew Dockstader]] in 1898]] '''George H. Primrose''' (November 12, 1852 - July 23, 1919) was a minstrel performer. He was one half of the comedy duo of [[Primrose and West]] with [[William H. West (entertainer)|William H. West]].<ref name=obit/>
==Biography== He was born on November 12, 1852, in [[London, Ontario]].<ref name=obit/>
His first wife, Emily Catlin, died in [[Chicago, Illinois]] in 1903.<ref>{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=Mrs. George Primrose Left $60,000 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/04/17/101390457.pdf |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=April 17, 1904 |accessdate=2015-04-02 }}</ref> He married Esther Nerney of [[San Francisco, California]] in [[Mount Vernon, New York]] on April 23, 1904.<ref>{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=Minstrel Weds Society Girl |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/04/24/118945139.pdf |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=April 24, 1904 |accessdate=2015-04-02 }}</ref> He wed for the third time to his secretary, Viola Katherine Trueblood, on April 15, 1916.<ref>{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=George Primrose, Old-Time Star in Minstrelsy, Takes Third Wife; Will Quit Stage Soon, He Says|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Fulton.html |newspaper=[[Rochester Democrat and Chronicle]] |date=April 16, 1916}}</ref>
He died in [[San Diego, California]] on July 23, 1919.<ref>{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=George Primrose Seriously Ill |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/07/23/97104568.pdf |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date= July 23, 1919 |accessdate=2015-04-02 }}</ref><ref name=obit>{{cite news |author= |title= George H. Primrose Dead |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/07/24/97105776.pdf |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=July 24, 1919 }}</ref>

revision.text:
'''''Gnuff''''' is a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[comic book]] series about an [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] dragon who lives in a city with his wife Gnellie and his son Gnicky. They keep their wings hidden (they are compact enough to be concealed under their clothing) and generally try to live quietly, being considered 'outsiders' in a [[Carl Barks]]-like world of contemporary [[funny animal]]s.
Gnuff first appeared in the Scandinavian [[fanzine]] ''Sejd'' (#12, 1974). Over the years, creator [[Freddy Milton]] has written and drawn many feature-length stories, resulting in a series of full-color albums, a regular Sunday-page newspaper comic strip, appearances in ''[[Critters (comics)|Critters]]'' and alongside [[Usagi Yojimbo]] <ref>[http://www.usagiyojimbo.com/other/comics/uy-cs1.html USAGI YOJIMBO Color Special #1 - From The Editors Desk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061217015740/http://usagiyojimbo.com/other/comics/uy-cs1.html |date=2006-12-17 }}</ref>
The Gnuff stories often revolve around social and environmental concerns. In an interview in ''[[Amazing Heroes]]'' #129, Milton said, "My dragons openly depict the problems of minorities. they have to conceal their old culture (their wings) to make it in our society. Also, they are a species on the decline. These are the reasons why they appeal to me." <ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/Paris/Metro/7211/fmart.html&date=2009-10-25+09:24:43 Interview from Amazing Heroes 129, 1987.]</ref>

{{about|the gamebook series|the Bernard Cornwell novels|The Grail Quest}} {{Infobox book series | name = GrailQuest | image = | image_caption = | books = {{plainlist| * ''The Castle of Darkness'' (1984) * ''The Den of Dragons'' (1984) * ''The Gateway of Doom'' (1984) * ''Voyage of Terror'' (1985) * ''Kingdom of Horror'' (1985) * ''Realm of Chaos'' (1986) * ''Tomb of Nightmares'' (1986) * ''Legion of the Dead'' (1987) }} | author = [[J. H. Brennan]] | editors = | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = [[John Higgins (comics)|John Higgins]] | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | genre = [[Fantasy]] | publisher = Armada (UK)
Dell (US) | pub_date = 1984 - 87 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print | number_of_books = 8 | list_books = | oclc = | preceded by = | followed by = | website = }} '''GrailQuest''' is a series of [[gamebook]]s by [[J. H. Brennan]]. The books are illustrated by [[John Higgins (comics)|John Higgins]]. The stories follow the adventures of a young hero named Pip, who is often called upon by [[Merlin]] to right wrongs and save the realm from evil. The series is light in tone and does not take itself seriously, often spoofing the fantasy genre and inserting slapstick humor or nonsensical elements. The series is mostly set in [[King Arthur]]'s realm of [[Avalon]], although the fourth volume, ''Voyage of Terror'', takes place almost entirely in [[ancient Greece]], after Merlin's summoning spell goes wrong. While there were eight total books published in the series, books seven and eight were never published in the United States. == Characters == *'''Pip''': The hero of the series. Pip was brought up on a farm as the adopted child of Freeman John and his wife Miriam. One day, soldiers from King Arthur's court arrived to escort Pip to Merlin's log castle, where Merlin assigned the young adventurer the mission of rescuing Queen [[Guinevere]] from the evil Wizard [[Ansalom]]. Pip fights (and sometimes argues) with a magical sword, Excalibur Junior, and often wears a sturdy dragonhide jacket when adventuring. Pip is never assigned a gender pronoun by anyone in the books and as such could be a female hero, though the assumption is usually taken that Pip is a young boy. Pip does declare himself '''lord''' of the jungle at one point, and EJ, referring to Pip, says "unhand him, varlet!". *'''Merlin''': The (supposedly) wise old wizard. He introduces each adventure and is usually the one who gives Pip his mission, providing Pip with items and some magic. Merlin tends to be sarcastic and grumpy, not to mention eccentric. However, even though he treats Pip like a foolish child, he still cares about the young adventurer. In one of the series' running jokes, Merlin acquires a new, bizarre home in every volume. *'''Cody''': Merlin's young apprentice, introduced in ''Legion of the Dead'', who brings Pip to Avalon via the Net Spell after Merlin disappears and is presumed dead following a fall from a tree. *'''Excalibur Junior (E.J.)''': Pip's magical talking sword. It was created by Merlin, who based its design on [[Excalibur|King Arthur's sword]] (hence the "Junior"). E.J. is quite powerful but has the annoying tendency of speaking its mind at inconvenient times, and can even refuse to be pulled from its scabbard (showing an ability similar to its namesake) when in a bad mood. E.J. also suffers from [[arachnophobia]], which is a disadvantage when Pip runs into giant spiders. *'''The Poetic Fiend''': A [[vampire]] [[poet]] who is a recurring character through the series. The Fiend believes that he is a great poet, when in actuality his verse tends more towards [[doggerel]] (and has been known to make even cockroaches throw up when he gives a recital). He is often helpful to Pip, as long as Pip is diplomatic in his criticism of the Fiend's poetry. In the English-language books, the Fiend is unnamed. In the French translations, however, he is known as Nosferax. *'''King Arthur''': Ruler of the realm of Avalon. He is rarely encountered by the player in person, but is a prominent and influential figure in the series. He is usually the one who gives missions to Pip by the way of Merlin. *'''King Pellinore''': [[King Pellinore of Listinoise]] appears in the first few books as a running gag, where he is often confused for the Black Knight because of his dark armor. Often it is Pellinore who is assigned the task of taking care of whatever problem is plaguing Camelot, with Pip only coming in later after the poor old king gets himself hopelessly lost. *'''The Wizard Ansalom''': An evil black-magic-using wizard, who is the main villain in the very first adventure. He returns as a ghost when Pip visits the Ghastly Kingdom of the Dead and Pip discovers that some of his dark influence remains in the last volume. *'''The Black Knight''': The [[Black Knight (Arthurian legend)|Black Knight]] of old legend is the main villain in one of Pip's adventures. He seems to appear in several volumes, but those other appearances are actually King Pellinore (see above). == Titles == # ''The Castle of Darkness'' (1984) # ''The Den of Dragons'' (1984) # ''The Gateway of Doom'' (1984) # ''Voyage of Terror'' (1985) # ''Kingdom of Horror'' (1985) # ''Realm of Chaos'' (1986) # ''Tomb of Nightmares'' (1986) # ''Legion of the Dead'' (1987) == Combat == The rules of GrailQuest are quite simple when compared to current [[role-playing game|RPG]]s. The player must roll two six-sided dice and add the results. If the result exceeds 6 (which will happen 58.3% of the time), then the enemy is injured and loses a number of [[hit point|Life Points]] - how much depends on what the dice shows, as every point over 6 will count as a point of damage. When a character's Life Points reach zero, the character is dead, and when they are at 5, they are knocked out. If wielding a weapon, the number needed to hit may be lower, and extra damage will usually be inflicted. For instance, Excalibur Junior hits on a roll of 4 (hitting 91.7% of the time) and provides a bonus 5 points of damage. There is no defence roll, but damage is reduced by a set amount by any armor the character is wearing. [[Initiative (role-playing games)|Initiative]] is determined by an initial, opposed roll where the highest roll gets the first attack. From then on, the character and the enemy take turns to attack. Surprise is sometimes involved (for example, in ''Gateway of Doom'', a giant spider gets first strike automatically due to Pip being in its home territory). If the character dies, the player must go to section 14, which describes his afterdeath and tells him to calculate his Life Points again. Merlin then resurrects Pip, who has to start from the beginning of the adventure again - although some books will only require him to start from a certain point, such as ''Gateway of Doom'' allows Pip to restart at the beginning of the Ghastly Kingdom of the Dead, or ''Realm of Chaos'' allows him to start from the beginning of a certain location. However, all previously killed enemies remain dead, and any treasure the player found is gone for good. (In some books, killed enemies return to life with half the Life Points they had the first time around.) == Magic spells == In some of the books, Merlin provides Pip with magic spells. In the first book, Pip has only two spells - ten firefingers (lightning bolts) and two powerful fireballs. The firefinger lightning bolts hit automatically for a straight 10 points of damage, while the fireballs score a massive 75 points of damage each, but require a 6 or better on two dice or else they miss completely. === Pip's First Spell Book === In the second book, Merlin provides Pip with a [[grimoire|spell book]]. This provides Pip with more spells of various uses in and out of combat. Pip also receives ten new firefingers (different from the firefingers on the previous book) and two new fireballs. If the player has finished the first book, he can keep any unspent spells from the previous book, and also the dragonhide jacket, which would otherwise be unavailable. Pip's use of magic is limited by three rules that must be adhered to at all times. First, every spell thrown costs three Life Points whether it is cast successfully or not. Second, no spell can be thrown more than three times in any given adventure (and once thrown, it is used whether or not it is successfully cast). And third, no spell thrown is successfully cast unless a 7 or better is rolled on two dice. *Pip's Armour of Nearly Impenetrable Coruscation (P.A.N.I.C. for short) - Throws a shimmering wall of light around the caster for the duration of a single combat, which deducts four points of damage scored against Pip in addition to any other protection or armour worn. *Pip's Outlandish Wallop (P.O.W. for short) - Adds +10 damage to the next attack Pip makes on top of any other attack bonuses. *Pip's Instant Levity and Laughter (P.I.L.L. for short) - Causes a single enemy to laugh so hard that he or she misses the next three consecutive turns in combat. *Pip's Attacking Dart (P.A.D. for short) - Allows Pip to launch a ranged attack for a straight 10 damage against an opponent who is otherwise out of combat range. An enemy hit with the dart can only counter-attack if he or she has ranged weaponry or spells of his or her own. *Pip's Immunity to Poison (P.I.P. for short) - If cast before poison is taken, it completely counteracts the effects of the poison. The spell does not function if cast after Pip has already been poisoned, however. *Pip's Instant Neutralizer (P.I.N. for short) - Counteracts one spell or enchantment placed on an object (not a living being). It is useful for opening a chest or door which has been magically locked, for example. *Pip's Immense Rapid Repeater (Pi R squared for short) - Doubles Pip's speed during a single combat, allowing Pip to get in two attacks for every one made by an opponent. *Invisibility (I.N.V.I.S.I.B.I.L.I.T.Y. for short) - This spell is an exception to the normal rules of magic in that it can only be cast once per adventure for a cost of 15 Life Points, and only in designated areas, but the effect renders Pip completely invisible. *Firefinger - This spell is an exception to the normal rules of magic in that it can only be successfully cast once per adventure. It gives Pip 10 Firefinger lightning bolts (five in each hand) which can be fired immediately or stored for later use. *Fireball - Like the Firefinger spell, it can only be successfully cast once per adventure. It gives Pip 2 fireballs which can be thrown immediately or stored for later use. === Pip's Second Spell Book === In the third book, Merlin provides Pip with a new spell book. When Pip wonders why this second spell book is shorter than the first one, Merlin tells Pip that spell books require a great deal of research and development, making them quite expensive, and he is not made of money. These spells follow the same three rules of magic described in the second book. *Pip's Patent Lock Picker (P.L.O.P. for short) - Will pick one non-magic lock per section on a throw of 6 or better on two dice. *Pip's Incredible Duncher (P.I.D. for short) - Creates a magical cap which, when worn, shrinks Pip to the size of six inches, thus allowing travel through small passageways. Pip returns to normal size in the next section. *Pip's Amazing Legume Spell (P.A.L.S. for short) - If Pip should come under attack by any sort of vegetable, this spell guarantees an automatic Friendly Reaction from said vegetable. *Pip's Instant Levitation (P.I.L. for short) - Allows Pip to levitate straight up or down, but if used indoors it causes a concussion when you hit the ceiling and the loss of half your current Life Points. *Pip's Obliging Power Sword (P.O.P.S. for short) - If cast before a hit roll in combat, it causes E.J. to score double damage on the next strike, but only half damage on the hit after that. Spell books, Firefingers, Fireballs, the dragonhide jacket and even E.J. are not available in the fourth book. Both spell books are also unavailable in books five and six; in the former case because Merlin has run out of time, and in the latter because no magic will work on account of the curse on Camelot. == Running Jokes == *In every book, once you are killed you have to turn to the infamous section 14. This rule is true for all of J.H. Brennan's gamebooks, except the ''[[Sagas of the Demonspawn|Demonspawn]]'' series where the killed player must go to the section 13. *Merlin's eccentricities are showcased in each book with Merlin acquiring a new dwelling, more bizarre and off-the-wall than the last. In ''Castle of Darkness'', Merlin lives in a log castle. He's moved to a crystal cave in ''Den of Dragons''. By ''Gateway of Doom'', he has moved into the lightning-blasted remains of an ancient druid oak. ''Voyage of Terror'' shows Merlin trying out a magical bubble spell which places a home of sorts at the bottom of the well in the town square of Glastonbury Village. In ''Kingdom of Horror'' he has created a home in the shape of a large six-sided die up in the Welsh Mountains. ''Realm of Chaos'' actually showcases two of Merlin's homes: the first being the enormous barrel-shaped house he is living in at the beginning, and the second one being a sort of abandoned fortress in the Astral Plane. ''Tomb of Nightmares'' has Merlin living inside a hollowed-out roc egg, presented to King Arthur by a drunken Arab sailor and given to the wizard when the King had no other idea of what to do with it. Only the final book in the series omits specific details about Merlin's home, though wherever it stands, there is a one-way door out of it which leads into Hell. *In ''Realm of Chaos'', Pip finds a book "about some idiot called Fire*Wolf", who is the hero of ''Demonspawn'', another series by J.H. Brennan. *Upon meeting Pip, most people recognize him as "...the one that put paid to old Ansalom, eh?" [[Ansalom]], as previously noted, was the villain in the first book. In addition, the further along in the series one gets, the more titles get appended to Pip's name. By the end of the series, Pip is known as the Wizard Basher, Dragon Slayer, Gateway Closer, Realm Saver, and Chaos Tamer and is often addressed by all of those titles at once by Merlin or E.J. and often at times when brevity would be far better for the circumstances. == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121102002829/http://mrparsons.webspace.virginmedia.com/html/grailquest_by_jh_brennan.html J H Brennan Book Covers & Info] *[http://www.herbiebrennan.com J H "Herbie" Brennan's personal website] *[http://www.gamebooks.org/show_series.php?id=188 Demians' Gamebook Web Page] Guide to GrailQuest gamebooks. revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox video game | title = I Hate Running Backwards | image = IHRB CoverArt.png | developer = Binx Interactive | publisher = [[Devolver Digital]] | series = | engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Nintendo Switch]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]] | released = {{Video game release|WW|22 May 2018}} | genre = [[Top-down shooter]], [[Roguelike]], [[Shoot 'em up]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] | programmer = {{Unbulleted list | Denis Mraović | Nikola Đurinec }} | artist = {{Unbulleted list | Matko Šimecki | Bernard Bachrach | Filip Kovač }} | composer = Damjan Mravunac }}
'''''I Hate Running Backwards''''' is a [[top-down shooter]] [[Roguelike|rogue-like]] [[Endless-runner|endless runner]] developed by Binx Interactive, produced by [[Croteam]] and published by [[Devolver Digital]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamereactor.eu/grtv/349953/I+Hate+Running+Backwards+Bernard+Bachrach+Interview/ |title=Gamereactor UK |website=www.gamereactor.eu}}</ref> It was developed for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Nintendo Switch]], [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://reboot.hr/binxov-i-hate-running-backwards-izdavat-ce-devolver-digital/ |title=Binxov I Hate Running Backwards izdavat će Devolver Digital - Reboot |date=31 August 2017 |publisher=}}</ref> It is an indie game which contains characters from the ''[[Serious Sam]], [[Nuclear Throne]], [[Broforce]], [[Shadow Warrior]], [[Enter the Gungeon|Enter The Gungeon]] and [[Hotline Miami]]'' series of [[video game]]s. The player picks a hero, who runs backwards and shoots downwards at enemies.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jutarnji.hr/kultura/gaming/hrvatski-kreatori-video-igara-klasicni-zanr-okrenuli-naglavacke-binx-interactive-je-saljivu-doskocicu-iz-serious-sama-pretvorio-u-zaraznu-pucacinu/6711777/ |title=HRVATSKI KREATORI VIDEO IGARA KLASIČNI ŽANR OKRENULI NAGLAVAČKE Binx Interactive je šaljivu doskočicu iz Serious Sama pretvorio u zaraznu pucačinu |publisher=}}</ref> The aestetic is described as similar to that of [[Minecraft]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2016-11-22-croteam-and-binx-a-very-croatian-collaboration |title=Croteam and Binx: a very Croatian collaboration |publisher=}}</ref> In addition to guns, the player will also be able to destroy obstacles, deflect projectiles using a melee weapon.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcpowerplay.com.au/feature/handson-preview-i-hate-running-backwards,479731 |title=Hands-on Preview: I Hate Running Backwards |publisher=}}</ref> The world of the game is completely destructible. The game was released on 22 May 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hcl.hr/vijest/najavljena-domaca-igra-i-hate-running-backwards-110768/ |title=Najavljena domaća igra I Hate Running Backwards - HCL.hr |publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/05/21/out-this-week-detroit-become-human-dark-souls-remastered-runner3</ref>
== Gameplay == [[File:CrystalUltimateGif.gif|thumb|Crystals ultimate ability in IHRB]] [[File:JungleA.png|thumb|Jungle Environment in IHRB]] ''I Hate Running Backwards'' is a top-down shooter rogue-like endless runner. The game has two main game modes. single player and local cooperative multiplayer mode. Single player mode can be extended with the daily run which has its own leader-board. The daily run can be played only once a day, it has a random character (even ones that the player hasn't unlocked yet) each day, and the generated world is predefined for all players to have a similar game-play experience. The player controls one of 12 characters, 9 of which must be unlocked through game-play. Each character has two different primary weapons they use, except the character "The Bullet", which has only one weapons. Each character also has a unique ability be it an ultimate ability that he/she has to charge or a passive ability that is always active. These abilities offer a different play-style for each of the characters.
The player progresses through 5 different environments that are procedurally generated. The environments follow a set path, the order is always Sand, Jungle, Medieval, Mines, Greek. At the end of every environment the player faces one of the games 6 bosses. The last environments boss, Ugh Zan, has two different forms, and it's fought as two different bosses. After killing the final boss the player enters a time portal that teleports them to the first environment but with increased difficulty. Loops can be run endlessly and get more difficult each time. Loops increase the number of enemies and all the games enemies can be spawned on all environments after the first loop. The increase in difficulty also raises the number of environmental traps that can kill the player.
Killing the games bosses unlocks shrines in the games lobby that can activate curses. Curses add additional mechanics to the game that makes it more difficult. The curses range from additional environmental traps, like poison, to death lasers that follow the player around the game world. Each curse also adds a modifier to the final score. The curses add a way for the players to naturally increase the difficulty to the point that suits them.
The player character starts of with a basic pistol weapon that has infinite ammo and a melee weapon. During gameplay the player can pickup ammo for his primary weapons or destroy weapon crates to get special weapons. The 34 special weapons each have a unique twist to them, for example the biomedic sniper can heal the player, while the gravity gun can group up enemies and make short work of them. The player unlocks new special weapons by completing different tasks in the game.
While playing the player defeats enemies and destroys the environment to gather Mojo, the games equivalent to experience. When enough mojo is gathered the player level ups and gains a perk which he can select from a group of three different perk per level. The perk he/she will get on the next level up is also indicated to make it possible to plan out builds one level in advance.
== Plot == ''I Hate Running Backwards'' is set in the universe of Serious Sam at an undisclosed moment in time. One of Mentals subordinates, Ugh-Zan has been put together from the parts of Ugh-Zan and Hugo and sent to the future to stop the group of heroes in fighting Mental. Ugh-Zans mind was uploaded to the new mechanized body and he can also transfer it to the tank module that is store inside his body as a last defense mode.
Sam and his group of heroes travel through time to defeat Mentals minions once and for all.
== Characters == [[File:SSPoseWiki.png|left|thumb|Serious Sam]] ''I Hate Running Backwards'' features characters from different franchises that were published by [[Devolver Digital]], with the exception of [[Nuclear Throne]] which was published and Developed by [[Vlambeer]]. The characters that are featured in the game are Serious Sam, Dancing Denzell and Fast Finger Freddie from the [[Serious Sam]] franchise, Richard from [[Hotline Miami]], Rambro from [[Broforce]], The Bullet from [[Enter the Gungeon]], Crystal from [[Nuclear Throne]] and Lo Wang from [[Shadow Warrior]]. The other 4 characters in game are unique characters from I Hate Running Backwards.
== Development == Development on ''I Hate Running Backwards'' started in 2016. The developers of the game, Binx Interactive are a small team consisting of only five developers who worked on video games as a hobby, but were showing up to game developer conferences in Croatia. On one of the Conferences [[Croteam]]s CEO Roman Ribaric and CMO Damjan Mravunac decided to give Binx a chance in their new incubator program. The idea of the program was to provide local developers with the support and equipment to make full-fledged video games.
The idea for the game came from Serious Sams catch phrase: "I hate running backwards" alluding to him constantly having to run backwards from enemies to avoid them killing him. The game was first structured as a simple action endless runner game with the focus on leading enemies into environmental traps that were spawned behind the player. The challenge in the game would come from the player having to avoid the same traps he would have to lead the enemies into. One of the games programmers, Denis Mraović came up with the idea to add the hammer swing mechanic into the game at one point, as he felt that the constant shooting tired him out, and he wanted to have something more to do during game-play.
The game was first shown to the public at Reboot-Infogamer in 2016. where the game won the best game-play award. The games hammer mechanic led the developers to introducing a redesign in graphics and the world. The whole game world was made destructible with the goal to make the experience more hands on. During the development cycle the game took shape as a rogue-like endless runner that turned the shoot-em-up genre on its head.
Somewhere during 2017. Croteam and BinxInteractive got [[Devolver Digital|Devolver-Digital]] on board as the games publisher. As the development moved on the team felt that they needed more distinct characters to fill the rooster of heroes. Devolver came up with the idea to use characters from their other IPs. Many of the games that inspired the team like ''[[Nuclear Throne|Nuclear throne]]'' and ''[[Enter the Gungeon]]'' had ties to Devolver directly or from previous projects. The game features twelve characters. Three characters are from the Serious Sam universe (Sam, Denzell and Fast Finger Freddie), Richard from [[Hotline Miami]], Rambro from [[Broforce]], The Bullet from [[Enter the Gungeon]], Crystal from [[Nuclear Throne]], Lo Wang from [[Shadow Warrior]] and 4 unique new characters (Dumpster Dave, Zombie Zed, Chux and Lady Death).
==Reception== The game was named as one of the best games at [[PAX East]] 2018 by [[GamesRadar]].<ref>https://www.gamesradar.com/pax-east-2018-best-games/2/</ref> ===Release=== The game received mixed reviews upon release on the PC platform, currently holding an aggregated score of 69 on [[Metacritic]].<ref>http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/i-hate-running-backwards</ref> [[PC PowerPlay]] gave it 8/10 stating "The game is really quite brutal, but individual runs quite short. It’s a perfect palate-cleaner game – quick to load, easy to switch to from other applications, and over pretty fast. Unless you’re good at it, which, you know… I’m pretty much not. But it’s also just wonderfully silly fun. Bright, chaotic in the all the best ways, and always surprising.".<ref>https://www.pcpowerplay.com.au/review/i-hate-running-backwards,491659</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Kris Duggan''' (July 10, 1974) is an [[Australia]]n-born [[entrepreneur]], advisor, investor, and educator.
In his career, Kris Duggan has advised and invested in a variety of Silicon Valley-based companies, including [[Palantir Technologies]], [[RelateIQ]] (acquired by [[Salesforce.com]]), [[Addepar]], Blend Labs, Turo, and Gusto.
In 2010, Duggan co-founded and was the founding CEO of Badgeville, which provided gamification and social engagement solutions to help companies influence and measure user behavior. Badgeville grew to over 100 employees and 300 customers prior to be being acquired by publicly traded CallidusCloud in 2016.
In 2013, Duggan co-founded and was the founding CEO of BetterWorks, an enterprise software company dedicated to innovating the field of performance management. BetterWorks is funded by Kleiner Perkins (board member John Doerr) and Emergence Capital (board member Jason Green). BetterWorks has almost 100 employees and serves over 250 customers. Kris Duggan presently serves on the Board of Directors at BetterWorks.
In 2018, Kris Duggan co-founded a new technology company, based in Palo Alto, CA.
Additionally, Duggan is an advisory chair to the Alchemist Accelerator, an organization which facilitates enterprise startups and advises new entrepreneurs. He previously served as an adjunct faculty for Singularity University, and is a frequent speaker on the topics of scaling startups, customer loyalty, gamification, employee engagement, and performance management.
== Life and education ==
Kris Duggan was born in [[Sydney, New South Wales]], and grew up in [[Houston, Texas]] and then Southern California. He graduated with an MBA in Information Technology from [[University of California, Irvine]]. He moved to Silicon Valley in 1999 and resides in Palo Alto with his wife and two sons.
== Career ==
'''BetterWorks'''
In 2013, Duggan co-founded BetterWorks, a Silicon Valley-based company dedicated to helping companies, managers and employees succeed at work<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.betterworks.com|title=The Continuous Performance Management Platform - BetterWorks|website=BetterWorks}}</ref> Rooted in the Objectives and Key Results ([[OKR]]s) method for goal setting, BetterWorks uses Goal Science™ principles to drive operational excellence for companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.betterworks.com/solutions/|title=Continuous Performance Management Process & Feedback Management|publisher=}}</ref> BetterWorks is funded by [[Kleiner Perkins]] (board member [[John Doerr]]) and Emergence Capital (board member Jason Green) and has raised $40M in capital. Duggan resigned as CEO of BetterWorks in July 2017, and as of February 2018, Duggan was an active board member.
'''Badgeville'''
Kris Duggan co-founded Badgeville in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/10/business/kris-duggan-of-badgeville-on-the-getting-stuff-done-index.html|title=Getting Stuff Done: It’s a Goal, and a Rating System|website=New York Times}}</ref> During his three-year tenure as CEO, the company raised $40M in capital, grew to over 100 employees, and secured over 300 customers.<ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/danschawbel/2014/12/01/kris-duggan-how-companies-can-master-goal-setting/</ref> Known as the Behavior Platform, Badgeville helped business leaders measure and influence behavior in both customer- and employee-facing user experiences.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://badgeville.com|title=Badgeville: The #1 Gamification Platform for the Enterprise|website=Badgeville}}</ref>
Badgeville’s customers included Deloitte, EMC, Oracle, Dell, AOL, Samsung, NBC, The Active Network, Recyclebank and Universal Music. The company received numerous awards including TechCrunch Disrupt's Audience Choice 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/02/12/techcrunch-disrupt-badgeville-lessons/|title=Lessons From TechCrunch Disrupt Audience Choice Winner Badgeville’s Launch|first=|last=Contributor|publisher=}}</ref> Forbes America's Most Promising New Companies,<ref>Forbes, America's Most Promising Companies List (2011-11-30). "America's Most Promising Companies, #92". Forbes</ref> LeWeb's Startup Finalist,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://paulamarttila.wordpress.com/2010/12/20/leweb10-startup-competition-why-super-marmite/|title=The Dos And Don’ts Of Startup Pitching – Why Super Marmite Crushed It And GreenPocket Didn’t #LeWeb10 Competition|date=20 December 2010|publisher=}}</ref> Twiistup's Showoff finalist,<ref>http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/twiistup-8-speakers-and-showoff-companies-announced-1383914.htm</ref> Forrester's Groundswell B2B and B2C,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forrester.com/Forrester+Research+Announces+The+2012+Forrester+Groundswell+Award+Winners+For+Excellence+In+Social+Media/-/E-PRE4344|title=Forrester : Marketing : Forrester Research Announces The 2012 Forrester Groundswell Award Winners For Excellence In Social Media|website=www.forrester.com}}</ref> and Gartner's Cool Vendor in Social CRM.<ref>Badgeville, Badgeville Named as Cool Vendor (May 2012). "Cool Companies". Forbes</ref> In its first three years, Badgeville was featured in more than 300 major media publications and outlets including features in the NY Times<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/10/business/kris-duggan-of-badgeville-on-the-getting-stuff-done-index.html|title=Kris Duggan of Badgeville, on the ‘Getting Stuff Done’ Index|first=Adam|last=Bryant|date=9 March 2013|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> and Wall Street Journal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204294504576615371783795248|title=Latest Game Theory: Mixing Work and Play|first=Rachel Emma|last=Silverman|date=10 October 2011|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> Publicly traded [[CallidusCloud]] acquired the company in 2016, and [[SAP SE|SAP]] acquired Callidus in 2018.
'''Addepar'''
From 2012 until 2014, Duggan served as an advisor to [[Addepar]], assisting with go-to-market strategy and execution.<ref name="crunchbase.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/kris-duggan|title=Kris Duggan - Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase}}</ref> During this period, [[Addepar]] launched a campaign targeting Registered Investment advisers. Addepar has since gone to raise over $140M in funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/06/08/addepar-raises-140-million-so-more-of-the-ultra-rich-can-know-exactly-what-theyre-doing-with-their-money/|title=Addepar raises $140 million so more of the ultra rich can know exactly what they’re doing with their money |website=TechCrunch}}</ref>
'''Palantir'''
From 2009 until 2013, Duggan served as an advisor to [[Palantir Technologies]], assisting with go-to-market strategy and execution.<ref name="crunchbase.com"/> He developed the company in a number of ways, including expansion into the federal government.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/business/2015/03/05/the-quantified-serf |title= The quantified Serf |website=The Economist}}</ref>
'''Socialtext'''
From 2006 until founding Badgeville, Duggan served as vice president of sales for [[Socialtext]], delivering enterprise social software for collaboration. Duggan helped drive business for Socialtext's comprehensive suite of social could apps.<ref name="crunchbase.com"/>
'''WebEx'''
From 2003 until 2006, Duggan held senior sales management positions with [[WebEx]] prior to its acquisition by [[Cisco]] for $3.2 billion.<ref name="crunchbase.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2007/03/15/cisco-buys-webex-for-32-billion/ |title= Cisco Buys WebEx for $32 billion |website=Tech Crunch}}</ref> The company is currently known as Cisco WebEx, and provides a host of virtual, on-demand collaboration software including web conferencing and videoconferencing.
== Teaching ==
Kris Duggan is an advisory chair to the Alchemist Accelerator, an organization which facilitates enterprise startups and advises new entrepreneurs. He was also an adjunct faculty member for [[Singularity University]].<ref>[http://agbeat.com/business-news/6-fresh-ways-motivate-millennials-company/ " 6 fresh ways to motivate the Millennials at your company"]. ''The American Genius''. December 18, 2014 Marti Trewe</ref>
== Controversy ==
On July 11, 2017, a former employee of BetterWorks named Beatrice Kim filed a civil lawsuit in Superior Court in San Francisco against the company, Duggan, and two other employees accusing them of sexual harassment and discrimination.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/07/14/betterworks-duggan-kim-assault-sexual-manner-lawsuit/|title=BetterWorks and CEO sued by ex-employee for alleged sexually suggestive assault|first=Josh|last=Constine|publisher=}}</ref> Duggan denied the allegations, but resigned his position as CEO of BetterWorks on July 26, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/betterworks-ceo-steps-down-following-allegations-assault-sexual-harassment-2017-7|title=BetterWorks CEO to step down following accusations of assault, sexual harassment|publisher=}}</ref> He later blogged about the entire experience on his personal blog.<ref>https://krisduggan.com/2018/02/05/moving-on-from-betterworks/</ref> The lawsuit was voluntarily dismissed on January 31, 2018.<ref>https://webapps.sftc.org/captcha/captcha.dll?referrer=https://webapps.sftc.org/ci/CaseInfo.dll?CaseNum=CGC17560052</ref>

[[Wireless local area network]] channels using [[IEEE 802.11]] protocols are sold mostly under the trademark [[Wi-Fi|WiFi]]. The [[IEEE 802.11|802.11]] standard provides several distinct [[Radio frequency|radio frequencies]] ranges for use in Wi-FI communications: 900 [[Hertz|MHz]] 2.4 [[GHz]], 3.6 GHz, 4.9 GHz, 5 GHz, 5.9 GHz and 60 GHz [[band (radio)|bands]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.radio-electronics.com/info/wireless/wi-fi/80211-channels-number-frequencies-bandwidth.php|title=WiFi Channels {{!}} WiFi Frequency Bands List {{!}} Radio-Electronics.com|website=www.radio-electronics.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-18}}{{cite web | url=https://standards.ieee.org/getieee802/802.11.html | title=IEEE 802.11-2007: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) specifications | publisher=[[IEEE]] |date=8 March 2007}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.lifewire.com/wireless-standards-802-11a-802-11b-g-n-and-802-11ac-816553|title=802.11 WiFi Standards Explained|work=Lifewire|access-date=2018-08-18|language=en}} Each range is divided into a multitude of [[Channel (communications)|channels]]. Countries apply their own regulations to the allowable channels, allowed users and maximum power levels within these frequency ranges. The [[ISM band]] ranges are also often used.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2010/09/wireless-explainer/|title=Why Everything Wireless Is 2.4 GHz|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-08-18|language=en-US}} =={{anchor|2.4GHz}} 2.4 GHz (802.11b/g/n/ax)== [[Image:2.4 GHz Wi-Fi channels (802.11b,g WLAN).svg|thumb|center|Graphical representation of {{nowrap|2.4 GHz}} band channels overlapping|399x399px]] ===Most countries=== [[File:NonOverlappingChannels2.4GHzWLAN-en.svg|thumb|center|upright=3.25|Graphical representation of Wireless LAN channels in 2.4 GHz band. Note "channel 3" in the 40MHz diagram above is often labelled with the 20MHz channel numbers "1+5" or "1" with "+ Upper" or "5" with "+ Lower" in router interfaces, and "11" as "9+13" or "9" with "+ Upper" or "13" with "+ Lower"]] ===United States=== [[File:NonOverlappingChannels2.4GHz802.11-en.svg|thumb|center|upright=3.0|Graphical representation of Wireless LAN channels in 2.4 GHz band. Note "channel 3" in the 40 MHz diagram above is often labelled with the 20MHz channel numbers "1+5" or "1" with "+ Upper" or "5" with "+ Lower" in router interfaces.]] Fourteen channels are designated in the 2.4 GHz range, spaced 5 MHz apart from each other except for a 12 MHz space before channel 14.{{cite web | url=https://standards.ieee.org/getieee802/802.11.html | title=IEEE 802.11-2012: 16.4.6 - PMD Operating Specifications, General | publisher=[[IEEE]] | date=15 May 2013}} For 802.11g/n, it is not possible to guarantee [[orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing]] (OFDM) operation, thus affecting the number of possible non-overlapping channels depending on radio operation.{{cite web | url=https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/wireless/technology/channel/deployment/guide/Channel.html#Moving_to_802.11g | website=www.cisco.com |title=Channel Deployment Issues for 2.4-GHz 802.11 WLANs |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070712140843/https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/wireless/technology/channel/deployment/guide/Channel.html |archivedate=12 July 2007 |accessdate=2 August 2017}} ===Interference concerns=== As the protocol requires 16.25 to 22 MHz of channel separation (as shown above), adjacent channels overlap and will interfere with each other. Leaving three or four channels clear between used channels is recommended to avoid interference.{{cite web |url=https://compnetworking.about.com/od/wifihomenetworking/qt/wifichannel.htm |title=Choosing the right Wi-Fi channel can minimize wireless interference | website=compnetworking.about.com | accessdate=5 June 2016}} The exact spacing required depends on the protocol and data rate selected as well as the electromagnetic environment where the equipment is used. When two or more 802.11b transmitters are operated in the same airspace, their signals must be attenuated by -50 dBr and/or separated by 22 MHz to prevent interference.{{cite web | url=https://standards.ieee.org/getieee802/802.11.html | title=IEEE 802.11-2012: 16.4.7.5 - Transmit spectrum mask | publisher=[[IEEE]] | date=15 May 2013}} This is because the DSSS algorithm transmits data logarithmically along a 20 MHz bandwidth. The remaining 2 MHz gap is used as a [[guard band]] to allow sufficient attenuation along the edge channels. This guardband is mainly used to accommodate older routers with modem chipsets prone to full channel occupancy, as most modern WiFi modems are not prone to excessive channel occupancy. :Note: The 40 MHz bands in the diagram above are labelled with their centre channel numbers, but the management interface of many Wi-Fi devices labels one of these bands with the centre channel of one of the 20 MHz bands it overlaps plus an Up or Down notation to specify the other half of the band. For example, channel 3 in the diagram is called channel 1+Upper or Channel 5+Lower, and Channel 11 in the diagram is called Channel 9+Upper or Channel 13+Lower. ''Nations apply their own RF emission regulations to the allowable channels, allowed users and maximum power levels within these frequency ranges. Network operators should consult their local authorities as these regulations may be out of date as they are subject to change at any time. Most of the world will allow the first thirteen channels in the spectrum.'' {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" |+ |- ! Channel ! F0 (MHz) ! class="unsortable" | [[North America|North
