{{no}} ||{{yes|'''11b Only'''}}{{ref|C|C}} || {{no}} |- |} {{note|B|B}}In the US, 802.11 operation on channels 12 and 13 is allowed under low power conditions. The 2.4 GHz Part 15 band in the US allows spread-spectrum operation as long as the 50 dB bandwidth of the signal is within the range of 2,400–2,483.5 MHz{{cite web |title=dead link |url=https://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c%3Decfr%3Bsid%3D9eab2402bb1cccc8f85bb3fa9e6c2daa%3Brgn%3Ddiv5%3Bview%3Dtext%3Bnode%3D47%3A1.0.1.1.16%3Bidno%3D47%3Bcc%3Decfr#47:1.0.1.1.16.3.234.31 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121212090129/http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr;sid=9eab2402bb1cccc8f85bb3fa9e6c2daa;rgn=div5;view=text;node=47:1.0.1.1.16;idno=47;cc=ecfr%2347:1.0.1.1.16.3.234.31#47:1.0.1.1.16.3.234.31 |dead-url=yes|accessdate=18 February 2014}} which fully encompasses both channels 12 and 13. A [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) document clarifies that only channel 14 is forbidden and that low-power transmitters with low-gain antennas may operate legally in channels 12 and 13.{{cite web | url=https://www.fcc.gov/oet/ea/presentations/files/oct05/Unlicensed_Devices_JD.pdf | page=58 | title=TCB workshop on unlicensed devices | date=October 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081105163502/http://www.fcc.gov/oet/ea/presentations/files/oct05/Unlicensed_Devices_JD.pdf | archivedate=5 November 2008}} Channels 12 and 13, however, are not normally used in order to avoid any potential interference in the adjacent restricted frequency band, 2,483.5–2,500 MHz,{{cite web | url=https://www.ntia.doc.gov/ntiahome/fccfilings/2005/cogradio/ETDocket03-108_02152005.htm#_ftn88 | title=NTIA Comments ET Docket No 03-108 02-15-2005 | website=www.ntia.doc.gov | accessdate=5 June 2016}} which is subject to strict emission limits set out in 47 CFR § 15.205.{{cite web | url=https://edocket.access.gpo.gov/cfr_2004/octqtr/pdf/47cfr15.205.pdf | website=Edocket.access.gpo.gov |title=47 CFR Ch. I (10–1–04 Edition) |accessdate=2 August 2017}} Per recent FCC Order 16-181, "an authorized access point device can only operate in the 2483.5–2495 MHz band when it is operating under the control of a Globalstar Network Operating Center and that a client device can only operate in the 2483.5–2495 MHz band when it is operating under the control of an authorized access point"{{cite web | url=https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-16-181A1.pdf | title=FCC 16-181 | date=23 December 2016 | website=apps.fcc.gov | accessdate=22 February 2017}} In Canada, 12 channels are available for use, 11 of which at full power and the other (channel 12) is transmit power limited. Few devices, however, have a method to enable a lower powered channel 12.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} {{note|C|C}}Channel 14 is valid only for [[DSSS]] and [[Complementary code keying|CCK]] modes (Clause 18 [[wiktionary:a.k.a.|a.k.a.]] [[802.11b]]) in Japan. [[OFDM]] (i.e., [[802.11g]]) may not be used. (IEEE 802.11-2007 §19.4.2) [[File:SHAW WiFi Router Channel Denial SEP 2018 v2.jpg|thumb|left|400px|An example of an ISP denying access to WiFi channels on a home router.These channels in Canada are available except CH 12. In this case note the denial of CH 11 is most notable and important as it is available for use in Canada, the other denied channels may be 40MHz wide.]] {{-}} ==3.65 GHz ([[802.11y]])== ''Except where noted, all information taken from Annex J of IEEE 802.11y-2008'' This range is documented as only being allowed as a licensed band in the United States. Please see [[IEEE 802.11y]] for details. Countries apply their own regulations to the allowable channels, allowed users and maximum power levels within these frequency ranges. A 40 MHz band is available from 3655–3695 MHz. It may be divided into eight 5 MHz channels, four 10 MHz channels, or two 20 MHz channels, as follows: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! rowspan=2 | Chan-
nel ! rowspan=2 | Fre-
quency
(MHz) ! colspan=3 | North America |- ! class="unsortable" | 5 MHz !! class="unsortable" | 10 MHz !! class="unsortable" | 20 MHz |- |131||3657.5||{{yes}}||{{no}}||rowspan=3 {{no}} |- |rowspan=2|132||3660.0||{{no}}||{{yes}} |- |3662.5||{{yes}}||rowspan=2 {{no}} |- |rowspan=3|133||rowspan=2|3665.0||rowspan=2 {{no}}||rowspan=2 {{yes}} |- |rowspan=2 {{no}} |- |3667.5||{{yes}}||rowspan=4 {{no}} |- |rowspan=2|134||3670.0||{{no}}||{{yes}} |- |3672.5||{{yes}}||rowspan=2 {{no}} |- |rowspan=3|135||rowspan=2|3675.0||rowspan=2 {{no}} |- |rowspan=2 {{no}}||rowspan=4 {{no}} |- |3677.5||{{yes}} |- |rowspan=2|136||3680.0||{{no}}||{{yes}} |- |3682.5||{{yes}}||rowspan=2 {{no}} |- |rowspan=3|137||rowspan=2|3685.0||rowspan=2 {{no}}||rowspan=2 {{yes}} |- |rowspan=2 {{no}} |- |3687.5||{{yes}}||rowspan=3 {{no}} |- |rowspan=2|138||3690.0||{{no}}||{{yes}} |- |3692.5||{{yes}}||{{no}} |- |} ==4.9 GHz ([[802.11j]]) public safety WLAN== 50 MHz of spectrum from 4940 MHz to 4990 MHz (WLAN channels 20–26) are in use by public safety entities in the United States. Within this spectrum space, there are two non-overlapping channels allocated, both with a width of 20 MHz. The most commonly used channels are 22 and 26. =={{anchor|5GHz}} 5 GHz (802.11[[802.11a|a]]/[[802.11h|h]]/[[802.11j|j]]/[[802.11n|n]]/[[802.11ac|ac]]/[[IEEE 802.11ax|ax]])== Source:IEEE 802.11-2007 Annex J modified by amendments k, y and n. Countries apply their own regulations to the allowable channels, allowed users and maximum power levels within these frequency ranges. Network operators should consult their local authorities as these regulations may be out of date as they are subject to change at any time. European standard [[ETSI#ETSI deliverable types|EN]] 301 893 covers 5.15–5.725 GHz operation, and v1.8.1 is in force.{{cite web | title=EN 300 328 V1.8.1 to be mandatory from 1st January 2015 | url=https://www.tuv-sud.co.uk/uk-en/about-tuev-sued/tuev-sued-in-the-uk/tuev-sued-product-service/tuev-sued-product-service-news/en-300-328-v1.8.1-to-be-mandatory-from-1st-january-2015 | accessdate=10 March 2015}} In 2007, the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]] ([[United States]]) began requiring that devices operating on 5.250–5.350 GHz and 5.470–5.725 GHz must employ [[dynamic frequency selection#DFS|dynamic frequency selection]] (DFS) and [[power control#Transmit Power Control|transmit power control]] (TPC) capabilities. This is to avoid interference with weather-radar and military applications.{{cite web | url=https://louise.hallikainen.org/FCC/FccRules/2011/15/407/ | website=louise.hallikainen.org |title=15.407 - General technical requirements |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323122829/https://louise.hallikainen.org/FCC/FccRules/2011/15/407/ |archivedate=23 March 2012 |accessdate=2 August 2017}} In 2010, the FCC further clarified the use of channels in the 5.470–5.725 GHz band to avoid interference with [[Terminal Doppler Weather Radar|TDWR]] weather radar systems.{{cite web | url=https://apps.fcc.gov/oetcf/kdb/forms/FTSSearchResultPage.cfm?id=41732&switch=P | title=Publication Number: 443999 Rule Parts: 15E | work=[[Federal Communication Commission]] | date=14 August 2014 | quote=Devices must be professionally installed when operating in the 5470 – 5725 GHz band}} In FCC parlance, these restrictions are now referred to collectively as the "Old Rules". On 10 June 2015, the FCC approved a "new" ruleset for 5 GHz device operation (called the "New Rules"), which adds 160 and 80 MHz channel identifiers, and re-enables previously prohibited DFS channels, in Publication Number 905462.{{cite web | title=905462 15.401 UNII, U-NII, DFS Test Procedures | url=https://apps.fcc.gov/oetcf/kdb/forms/FTSSearchResultPage.cfm?switch=P&id=27155 |website=apps.fcc.gov |accessdate=8 August 2015 | author=FCC Office of Engineering and Technology}} This FCC publication eliminates the ability for manufacturers to have devices approved or modified under the Old Rules in phases; the New Rules apply in all circumstances as of 2 June 2016. Germany requires DFS and TPC capabilities on 5.250–5.350 GHz and 5.470–5.725 GHz as well; in addition, the frequency range 5.150–5.350 GHz is allowed only for indoor use, leaving only 5.470–5.725 GHz for outdoor and indoor use.{{cite web |url=https://www.bundesnetzagentur.de/SharedDocs/Downloads/DE/Sachgebiete/Telekommunikation/Unternehmen_Institutionen/Frequenzen/Allgemeinzuteilungen/2010_07_WLAN_5GHz_pdf.pdf?__blob=publicationFile |title=Bundesnetzagentur Vfg 7/2010 / See footnote 4 and 5 (German only) |accessdate=2 August 2017}} Since this is the German implementation of EU Rule 2005/513/EC, similar regulations must be expected throughout the European Union.{{cite web | url=https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32005D0513:EN:NOT | title=EUR-Lex - 32005D0513 - EN - EUR-Lex | website=eur-lex.europa.eu | accessdate=5 June 2016}}{{cite web | url=https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32007D0090:EN:NOT | title=EUR-Lex - 32007D0090 - EN - EUR-Lex | website=eur-lex.europa.eu | accessdate=5 June 2016}} Austria adopted Decision 2005/513/EC directly into national law.[https://www.bmvit.gv.at/ofb/publikationen/infoblaetter/downloads/201005en.pdf Information of the Austrian Telecommunications Authority - Wireless Local Area Networks (WAS, WLAN, RLAN)] The same restrictions as in Germany apply, only 5.470–5.725 GHz is allowed to be used outdoor and indoor. Source for South Africa: {{cite web |url=https://www.icasa.org.za/uploads/files/Radio-Frequency-Spectrum-Regulations-2015.pdf |website=www.icasa.org.za |title=The Radio Frequency Spectrum Regulations 2015 |accessdate=10 September 2018}} Japan's use of 10 and 20 MHz-wide 5 GHz wireless channels is codified by [[Association of Radio Industries and Businesses]] (ARIB) document STD-T71, ''Broadband Mobile Access Communication System (CSMA)''.{{cite web | title=List of ARIB Standards for Radio | url=https://www.arib.or.jp/english/html/overview/st_ej.html | website=www.arib.or.jp | accessdate=19 January 2016}} Additional rule specifications relating to 40, 80, and 160 MHz channel allocation has been taken on by Japan's [[Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications]] (MIC).{{cite web | title=Wi-Fi Amateur: IEEE Std 802.11ac Deployment in Japan | url=https://wifiamateur.blogspot.com/2013/04/80211ac-device-deployment-in-japan.html | website=wifiamateur.blogspot.com | date=3 April 2013 | accessdate=19 January 2016 | first=Chun "johnson" | last=Hou}} In Brazil, the TPC use in 5.150–5.725 GHz band is optional. DFS is required only in the 5.470–5.725 GHz band.{{cite web | url=https://www.anatel.gov.br/legislacao/resolucoes/2008/104-resolucao-506 | title=Brazil: Resolução nº 506, de 01/07/2008, publicado no Diário Oficial de 07/07/2008 (in Brazilian Portuguese) | access-date=2017-08-02 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170802212525/http://www.anatel.gov.br/legislacao/resolucoes/2008/104-resolucao-506 | archive-date=2017-08-02 | dead-url=yes | df= }} As of 2015, some of the Australian channels require DFS to be utilised (a significant change from the 2000 regulations, which allowed lower power operation without DFS). As per AS/NZS 4268 B1 and B2, transmitters designed to operate in any part of 5250–5350 GHz and 5470–5725 GHz bands shall implement DFS in accordance with sections 4.7 and 5.3.8 and Annex D of ETSI EN 301 893 or alternatively in accordance with FCC paragraph 15.407(h)(2). Also as per AS/NZS 4268 B3 and B4, transmitters designed to operate in any part of 5250–5350 MHz and 5470–5725 MHz bands shall implement TPC in accordance with sections 4.4 and 5.3.4 of ETSI EN 301 893 or alternatively in accordance with FCC paragraph 15.407(h)(1). New Zealand regulation differs from Australian.https://www.rsm.govt.nz/cms/licensees/types-of-licence/general-user-licences/short-range-devices Singapore regulatory - IMDA requires DFS and TPC capabilities on 5.250–5.350 GHz above 100 mW (e.i.r.p.) and below or equal to 200 mW (e.i.r.p.), requires DFS capability on 5.250–5.350 GHz below or equal to 100 mW (e.i.r.p.), and requires DFS and TPC capabilities on 5.470-5.725 below or equal to 1000mW (e.i.r.p.). Operating 5.725-5.850 GHz above 1000mW and below or equal to 4000mW (e.i.r.p) shall be approved on exceptional basis.{{cite web |url=https://www.imda.gov.sg/-/media/imda/files/regulation-licensing-and-consultations/ict-standards/telecommunication-standards/radio-comms/imdatssrd.pdf?la=en |title=IMDA Technical Specification Short Range Devices - Issue 1 Rev 1, April 2018 / See Page 13 & 14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224202955/https://www.ida.gov.sg/~/media/Files/PCDG/Licensees/StandardsQoS/RadiocomEquipStd/TSSRD.pdf |archivedate=24 February 2015 |accessdate=7 September 2018}} {{anchor|regulatory_tables5.0ghz}} {| class="wikitable sortable" ! style="text-align: center;" | Chan-

style="text-align: center;" | New Zealand |- |} China MIIT expanded allowed channels as of 31 December 2012 to add UNII-1, 5150 ~ 5250 GHz, UNII-2, 5250 ~ 5350 GHz (DFS/TPC), similar to European standards EN 301.893 V1.7.1.{{cite web | url=https://www.miit.gov.cn/n11293472/n11293832/n12843926/n13917072/15140529.html | website=www.miit.gov.cn |title=工业和信息化部发布5150-5350兆赫兹频段无线接入系统频率使用相关事宜的通知 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530151754/http://www.miit.gov.cn/n11293472/n11293832/n12843926/n13917072/15140529.html |archivedate=30 May 2013 |accessdate=2 August 2017}} =={{anchor|5.9GHz}} 5.9 GHz (802.11p)== The [[802.11p]] amendment, also known as Wireless Access in Vehicular Environments (WAVE), published on 15 July 2010, specifies WLAN in the licensed [[Intelligent Transportation Systems]] (ITS) band of 5.9 GHz (5.850–5.925 GHz).{{cite web | url=ftp://140.118.9.75/yhl/mobile12/802.11p-intro.pdf | last1=Jiang | first1=Daniel | last2=Delgrossi | first2=Luca | title=IEEE 802.11p: Towards an International Standard for Wireless Access in Vehicular Environments | publisher=IEEE | accessdate=28 December 2013 | date=2008 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The 802.11p standard is intended for use in [[vehicular communication systems]]. ==60 GHz (802.11ad/ay)== The [[802.11ad]]/[[802.11ay|ay]], also known as [[WiGig]]. This operates in 60 GHz [[ISM band]]. ==900 MHz (802.11ah)== [[802.11ah]] operates in sub-gigahertz unlicensed bands. Each world region supports different sub-bands, and the channels number depends on the starting frequency of the sub-band it belongs to. Thus, there is no global channels numbering plan, and the channels numbers are incompatible between world regions (and even between sub-bands of a same world region). The following sub-bands are defined in the [[802.11ah]] specifications: {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Region ! Subband
(MHz) ! Bandwidths
(MHz) |- | rowspan="2" | Australia | style="text-align: center;" | 915–920 | 1, 2, 4 |- | style="text-align: center;" | 920–928 | 1, 2, 4, 8 |- | rowspan="2" | China | style="text-align: center;" | 755–779 | 1 |- | style="text-align: center;" | 779–787 | 1, 2, 4, 8 |- | Europe | style="text-align: center;" | 863–868 | 1, 2 |- | Japan | style="text-align: center;" | 916.5–927.5 | 1 |- | Korea | style="text-align: center;" | 917.5–923.5 | 1, 2, 4 |- | rowspan="2" | New
Zealand | style="text-align: center;" | 915–924 | 1, 2, 4, 8 |- | style="text-align: center;" | 924–928 | 1, 2, 4 |- | rowspan="2" | Singapore | style="text-align: center;" | 866–869 | 1, 2 |- | style="text-align: center;" | 920–925 | 1, 2, 4 |- | rowspan="3" | United
States{{Cite web|url=http://www.l-com.com/content/Article.aspx?Type=N&ID=10421|title=Advantages and Disadvantages of ISM Band Frequencies|website=L-com Global Connectivity|language=en-us|access-date=2018-08-18}} | style="text-align: center;" | 902–904 | 1, 2 |- | style="text-align: center;" | 904–920 | 1, 2, 4, 8, 16 |- | style="text-align: center;" | 920–928 | 1, 2, 4, 8 |} ==See also== * [[Electromagnetic interference at 2.4 GHz]] * [[High Speed Multimedia Radio]] * [[IEEE 802.11#Layer 2 .E2.80.93 Datagrams]] * [[Wireless LAN]] ==References== ==Further reading== * {{cite web | url=https://wireless.wiki.kernel.org/en/developers/regulatory | title=Regulatory Database | work=Linux Wireless — An online database of allowed frequencies used by [[Linux]] 802.11 subsystem}} * {{cite web | url=https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/wireless/aironet-1300-series/prod_white_paper0900aecd801c4a88.html | title=FCC Regulations Update | website=www.cisco.com — Dynamic Frequency Selection for 5 GHz WLAN in the U.S. and Canada}} {{DEFAULTSORT:WLAN channels}} [[Category:Wireless networking]] [[Category:Wi-Fi]] [[Category:IEEE 802.11]] [[Category:Radio-related lists]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = MYTV Broadcasting | logo = MYTV Malaysia Logo.png | type = Private | industry = [[Broadcasting]], [[digital terrestrial television]] provider | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2014|11|19}} in [[Cyberjaya]], [[Selangor]], [[Malaysia]] | founder = | hq_location_city = Cyberjaya | hq_location_country = Malaysia | areas_served = Nationwide | key_people = Michael Chan ([[CEO]]) | products = Television broadcasting | owner = Altel Holdings
MYTV Broadcasting Sdn Bhd | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = | website = {{URL|http://www.mytvbroadcasting.my/}} }} '''MYTV Broadcasting''' or '''MYTV''' is a Malaysian television broadcasting company providing free [[digital terrestrial television]] in the country, considered a first of its kind in the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.therakyatpost.com/news/2014/06/05/malaysia-pioneer-digital-terrestial-television-broadcasting-services/|title=Malaysia to pioneer digital terrestrial television broadcasting services|work=[[Bernama]]|publisher=The Rakyat Post|date=5 June 2014|accessdate=3 August 2015}} It is owned by Altel Holdings/Altel Communications and was planned to start broadcasting by mid-2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/business/article/mytv-to-offer-services-a-year-earlier-than-planned|title=MyTV to offer services a year earlier than planned|work=[[The Edge (Malaysia)|The Edge Financial Daily]]|publisher=[[The Malaysian Insider]]|date=18 August 2014|accessdate=3 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510183104/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/business/article/mytv-to-offer-services-a-year-earlier-than-planned|archivedate=10 May 2015|df=dmy-all}} The DTT service is officially branded as '''myFreeview''' since August 2015, though the legal name of the company remained unchanged.{{cite web |url= https://www.myfreeview.tv/ENG/about.html |title= myFreeview home page |accessdate= 13 October 2016}} A billion [[Malaysian ringgit|MYR]] deal have been signed with [[Telekom Malaysia]] to distribute the services.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2014/11/19/MyTV-inks-RM1bil-accord-with-TM-It-is-to-provide-digital-terrestrial-television-services-in-the-coun/?style=biz|title=RM1bil deal to provide digital terrestrial television in Malaysia|author=Daniel Khoo|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=19 November 2014|accessdate=3 August 2015}} The set top box has been available for sale as of February 2017, after long delays of building infrastructure and other issues.{{cite web|url=http://mytvbroadcasting.my/peta2.html|title=Liputan Siaran (Broadcast Coverage)|language=Malay|publisher=MYTV Broadcasting|accessdate=8 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.myfreeview.tv/ENG/howto.html|title=HOW TO RECEIVE MYFREEVIEW DIGITAL BROADCAST|accessdate=27 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/mytvbroadcasting/posts/1170260416325813|title= MYTV statement on Facebook |language=Malay|date=13 May 2016|accessdate=19 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.maybank2u.com.my/iwov-resources/investment-bank/document/my/en/research/2016/February%202016%20-%20Sector%20Research%20-%20Malaysia%20Media%20-%20TV%20Digitalization%20In%20Full%20Swing.pdf|title=TV digitization in full swing|date=16 February 2016|accessdate=25 May 2016}} Its in-house service MyFreeview was officially launched at 6 June 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.theedgemarkets.com/event-created/day/2017-06-06|title=Event for 6 June 2017|publisher=The EDGE Markets|date=6 June 2017|accessdate=6 June 2017}} Its main competitor would be the free-to-view satellite based service [[Astro NJOI]] which has far more channels to view. Current coverage for this service is roughly 93% of population, to which it will expand to 98% in the future.{{cite web|url=http://www.theedgemarkets.com/article/mytv-waive-fees-june-2018|title=MYTV to waive fees up to June 2018|date=19 June 2017|accessdate=20 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.myfreeview.tv/coverage|title= Coverage from myFreeview website|accessdate=16 November 2018}} == History == === Developments === Taiwanese company Allion Labs, Inc. has been awarded accreditation from the [[Sirim|Standards and Industrial Research Institute of Malaysia]] (SIRIM) to become the first lab facility for digital television in Malaysia.{{cite web|url=http://www.allion.com/news.html|title=Allion Becomes World’s First Laboratory to Provide Digital Terrestrial TV Broadcast Receiver Testing for the Malaysian Market|author=Allion Labs, Inc.|publisher=Allion Labs, Inc.|date=9 April 2015|accessdate = 25 January 2016}} Around 30 channels have been set to broadcast in the first stage.{{cite web|url=http://www.utusan.com.my/berita/nasional/30-saluran-percuma-tv-1.110526|title=30 saluran percuma TV|author=Zamzurina Ahmad|language=Malay|publisher=[[Utusan Malaysia]]|date=5 July 2015|accessdate=3 August 2015}} [[HbbTV]] services are also integrated into MYTV service with the usage of Sofia Digital's HbbTV technology.{{cite web|url=https://sofiadigital.com/sofia-digitals-hbbtv-technology-delivered-to-malaysian-rtm/|title= Sofia Digital’s HbbTV technology delivered to Malaysian RTM|date=11 March 2016|accessdate=27 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://sofiadigital.com/new-tv-services-case-example/|title= New TV services – Case example|accessdate=2 June 2017}} ==== First phase ==== East Coast Peninsular Malaysia has been chosen as the first site for testing followed by [[East Malaysia]], and northern and southern Peninsular Malaysia before reaching [[Klang Valley]]. In [[Sabah]], around 1,500 households have been selected for the test.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=101279|title=New Sabah digital TV experience|publisher=Daily Express|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=3 August 2015}} ==== Transmission fee ==== According to MYTV, the initial annual rental fee for a 24-hour free-to-air TV channel was RM 12 million for a SDTV channel and RM 25 million for a HDTV channel for a continuous 24 hour slot. However, following reports of [[Media Prima]] might quit free-to-air transmission due to unviable fees,{{cite web|url=http://www.theedgemarkets.com/my/article/media-prima-may-exit-fta-space-due-unviable-dtt-fee|title=Media Prima may exit FTA space due to unviable DTT fee|date=9 May 2016|accessdate=25 May 2016}} MYTV may introduce bandwidth based charging, which is already in consideration.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} On a statement given by MYTV CEO Michael Chan announced that transmission fees will be waived until June 2018, when Malaysia completes DTT migration by terminating analogue transmission. Rebates will be also given on a case-by-case basis for six months up to the end of 2018. He is also looking to bring the transmission fee down to between RM8 million and RM18 million, since the Malaysian TV market do not accept fees of RM12 million or RM25 million per channel. The transmission cost for each SD and HD channel was eventually revised to RM6.7 milion and RM7.4mil respectively per year. {{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2018/11/02/mytv-in-payment-dispute-with-tm/#6wOi0s4DfdOC5BRe.99|title= MYTV in payment dispute with TM |publisher= The Star (Malaysia)| date=2 November 2018|accessdate=16 November 2018}} === Distributions === According to former Malaysian Communication and Multimedia Minister [[Ahmad Shabery Cheek]], the MYTV Basic decoder would be distributed to around two million select Malaysian households while other recipients would be determined later.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Metro/Community/2015/07/10/Transmitters-installed-East-coast-cities-to-receive-trial-MYTV-service-in-digital-format/|title=East coast cities to receive trial MYTV service in digital format|author=Ong Han Sean|publisher=The Star|date=10 July 2015|accessdate=3 August 2015}} All 2 million households had now been determined and it would be sent to recipients house via PosLaju. ==== Types of decoders used by MYTV Broadcasting ==== There would be 3 types of set top boxes planned for use by MYTV, all with approved certification by "DTTV Malaysia". The first one is the trial test decoder, which was distributed to selected households for test transmission (which itself need to return to MYTV andeventually replaced by MYTV Basic STB). There are two standard set-top boxes issued, the first being the "MYTV Basic" decoder to be given to 2 million selected households nationwide for free, while the other is the standard "MYTV Advance" decoder, which is sold for RM299 excluding GST at [[Pos Malaysia]] branches and selected electrical stores. CI slots comes as a standard for both set top boxes, which it may be used for pay TV in the future.{{cite web|url= http://mytvbroadcasting.my/panduanpemasangan2.html|title=MYTV Installation Guide |language=Malay|publisher=MYTV Broadcasting|accessdate=12 September 2016}} The major differences for these set-top boxes is the latter one (MYTV Advance) comes with support for HbbTV while MYTV Basic did not come with such support. MYTV has sign an agreement with [[Pensonic]] to distribute MYTV Advance set top box exclusively on 29 November 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2016/11/29/pensonic-to-distribute-mytv-advance-decoder-sets/ |title= Pensonic to distribute MYTV Advance decoder sets|author=Tan Sin Chow|publisher=The Star (Malaysia)|date=29 November 2016|accessdate=15 December 2016}} Digital televisions with "DTTV Malaysia" certification can also be used to receive transmission.{{cite web|url=http://mytvbroadcasting.my/FAQ.html|title=MYTV FAQ |language=Malay|publisher=MYTV Broadcasting|access-date=12 September 2016}} ==== Requirements to receive a free MYTV test decoder (known as MYTV Basic) ==== * Did not subscribe to paid broadcasts. * Came from low-income group. * Included in the category of recipients of government aid. While households that are not listed as recipients of government aid could get the free decoders from branches which would be set up in every state after the launch in 2017. The temporary decoder would be replaced with a new decoder (known as MYTV Basic) in the final DTT test broadcasts at the end of 2016 with remote areas being distributed by [[Pos Malaysia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=101426|title=1,500 Sabah households for digital broadcast tests|publisher=[[Daily Express (Malaysia)|Daily Express]]|date=11 July 2015|access-date=3 August 2015}} == Services == === List of channels and services on MyFreeview === The following channels and services are carried or planned to be carried on MyFreeview platform:{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aJakG7mPYx8|title=MYTV Broadcasting DTT Trial + Singapore DTT (Updated 2 June 2017)}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! TV channels !! Radio channels !! OTT/Interactive services |- | * [[TV1 (Malaysia)|TV1]] * [[TV2 (Malaysia)|TV2]] * [[TV3 (Malaysia)|TV3]] (HD) * [[NTV7]] * [[8TV (Malaysia)|8TV]] * [[TV9 (Malaysia)|TV9]] * [[TV Alhijrah]] (HD) * [[Bernama News Channel]] * [[TV Okey]] * [[RTM HD Sports]] (test broadcast since 13 June 2018) * Drama Sangat (test broadcast) * [[CJ Group|CJ Wow Shop]] (test broadcast) * [[Channel W]] || * [[Nasional FM]] * [[Traxx FM]] * [[Minnal FM]] * [[Ai FM]] || * RTM Superteks (text service) * RTM MyKlik (video service) * Media Prima OTT service |} === Transmitters and frequencies === According to MYTV, there are 13 test phase sites which will be operate on the first stage, which it currently covers around 80% of population. MYTV will eventually develop 60 main transmitters and 40 gap fillers which it will cover 98% of population. Based on the information provided by myFreeview, 34 transmission sites are utilized to cover around 93% of Malaysian population via outdoor antenna. ==Controversy== myFreeview viewers residing in some/all parts of Sabah, Sarawak, Kelantan, Terengganu, Pahang, Negeri Sembilan, Melaka and Perak are facing prolonged no transmission issues since 11 and 25 October 2018, which 20 of 34 transmission sites has been taken down due to a payment dispute between Telekom Malaysia (TM) and MYTV Broadcasting. The remaining 14 sites was planned to taken down by TM at 1 November but those sites was eventually not taken down after intervention by the Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission (MCMC). This dispute places analogue switch-off, which is planned on first quarter of 2019, in question. {{cite web|url=https://www.mcmc.gov.my/media/press-releases/mytv-tm-urged-to-resolve-the-digital-tv-service-di|title= MYTV-TM Urged To Resolve The Digital TV Service Disruption| date=14 November 2018|accessdate=16 November 2018}} Digital TV transmission on all 20 affected sites was fully restored on 30 November 2018, when both parties reached a compromise. {{cite web|url=http://www.theedgemarkets.com/article/mytvs-digital-tv-service-back-air-says-gobind|title= MYTV's digital TV service back on air, says Gobind||publisher=The Edge (Malaysia)| date=30 November 2018|accessdate=1 December 2018}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.mytvbroadcasting.my/}} {{Malaysia TV}} {{CATV Africa, Asia, and Oceania}} {{MSC Malaysia}} [[Category:Privately held companies of Malaysia]] [[Category:2014 establishments in Malaysia]] [[Category:Media companies established in 2014]] [[Category:Television in Malaysia]] [[Category:Digital terrestrial television in Malaysia]]

The '''[[music industry]] of [[East Asia]],''' a region that includes Mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, Japan, Mongolia, North Korea, South Korea and Taiwan is a rapidly growing [[economic sector]] that is home to some of the world's largest music markets. == Milestones == [[File:Map_of_East_Asia.png|thumb|312x312px|Modern East Asia]] In 2003, [[South Korea]] became the world's first music market where digital music sales surpassed those of physical formats.{{cite web|last=Marchand|first=Ruby|title=Trade Mission Engages Key Korean Music Professionals|url=http://www.grammy.com/blogs/trade-mission-engages-key-korean-music-professionals|publisher=[[Grammy Award]]|accessdate=2013-01-14|quote=...It's also the first country where digital surpassed physical sales.}}{{cite book|last=McClure|first=Steve|title=Billboard Vol. 118, No. 18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6hUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA23|publisher=Billboard|year=2006|issn=0006-2510|page=23}} In 2012, [[Japan]] surpassed the [[United States]] as the world's largest recorded music market for the first time, according to the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]]. Though the U.S. remained the largest if licensing fees are included into the figures.{{cite web|title=Japan surpasses US as world's biggest recorded music market|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/business/tech-biz/04/09/13/japan-surpasses-us-worlds-biggest-recorded-music-market|author=[[Kyodo News]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News Channel]]|date=9 April 2013|accessdate=7 May 2013}} However, in the following year, Japan fell back to the second-largest music market after experiencing a 16.7 per cent decrease due to the country's reliance of CDs and slow adoption of digital services.{{cite web|title=Japan drags down global music market|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-26626396|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=18 March 2014|accessdate=6 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303287804579447222439275740|title=Japan Hits a Sour Note on Music Sales|author1=Karp, Hannah|author2=Inada, Miho|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=18 March 2014|accessdate=6 June 2015}} In 2015, the digital music market in [[China]] is expected to be worth {{USD|2.1 billion}}.{{cite web |url=https://www.techinasia.com/china-streaming-music-baidu-alibaba-battle/|title=Already bigger than Spotify, China’s search engine giant doubles down on streaming music|author=Steven Millward|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=December 4, 2015|work=Tech In Asia}} China is expected to become one of the largest music markets in the world by 2020.{{cite web |url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/epaper/2015-12/21/content_22763869.htm|title=Music industry dreaming of China streaming|author=Chen Nan|date=December 21, 2015|accessdate=August 13, 2016|work=[[China Daily]]}} == Contrast with the global music industry == Although global physical music sales (such as CDs) have been declining in recent years, in [[East Asia]] (particularly [[Japan]] and [[South Korea]]), however, physical music sales have been rising consistently. The [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]] credits this phenomenon to "[[K-Pop]] fans who want high-quality physical formats and deluxe box sets".{{cite web|url= http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/digital-and-mobile/1549940/francis-keeling-universal-musics-global-head-of-digital|title= Francis Keeling, Universal Music’s Global Head of Digital Business: Google Streaming Service ‘Is the Biggest Funnel We Can Have’|accessdate= 7 May 2013|publisher=''[[Billboard magazine]]''|quote=According to IFPI, global physical format sales declined from 61% in 2011 to an estimated 58% in 2012. However, in Japan, CD and DVD sales posted strong increases (sales numbers or percentages were not provided). While in South Korea physical sales are expected to rise for the third consecutive year, with IFPI crediting K-Pop fans who want high-quality physical formats and deluxe box sets, with driving the format's sustained popularity.}} According to a music executive from [[Universal Music Group]], CDs are becoming "the new merchandise in Asia".{{cite web|last=Lindvall|first=Helienne|title=How K-Pop & J-Pop Are Saving Physical Music Sales|url=http://www.digitalmusicnews.com/permalink/2013/20130410kpopjpop|publisher=Digital Music News|accessdate=7 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518191654/http://www.digitalmusicnews.com/permalink/2013/20130410kpopjpop|archivedate=18 May 2013|df=}} == Controversy == Several controversies have arrived based on the way the industry has been treating its artists. === Control of artists personal lives === It is not uncommon for record labels to prohibit their pop artists from dating for a certain period of time or for as long as they have a contract with the company.{{Cite news|url=https://japantoday.com/category/entertainment/3-ways-the-japanese-entertainment-industry-keeps-idol-singers-from-dating|title=3 ways the Japanese entertainment industry keeps idol singers from dating|work=Japan Today|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en}} In Japan managers may attempt to discourage their artists from dating or engaging in behavior that may tarnish their images by keeping a busy schedule and only letting artists know about their schedules a day at a time. Artists who break this contract, as in the case of [[Minami Minegishi]] from [[AKB48]], run the risk of getting dropped from their music group or contract.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-35368705|title=The dark side of Asia’s pop music industry|last=Oi|first=Mariko|date=2016|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-GB}} Korea has similar rules for musical pop artists. Artists have more freedom to date and get married, however managers have strong control over their personal lives and behaviors. In Taiwan, artists are also expected to behave in certain ways, as they cannot discuss taboo topics such as politics. == Ranking == The following table lists the total revenues of the music markets of East Asia: {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="text-align:center; font-size:100%" ! Rank ! href="slave contract" | Country ! Revenue in 2014
(in million USD) ! Growth rate |- Source |- | 1 | style="text-align:left;" | {{JPN}} | 2627.9 | -5.5% |- {{cite web |url=http://www.riaj.or.jp/e/issue/pdf/RIAJ2015E.pdf#page=26|title=RIAJ Yearbook 2015: IFPI 2013, 2014. Global Sales of Recorded Music|date=2015-04-24|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of Japan]]|format=PDF|page=24|accessdate=2015-06-06}} |- | 2 {{KOR}} | 265.8 | 19.2% |- |- | 3 {{CHN}} (PRC) | 105.2 | 5.6% |- |- | 4 {{TWN}} | N/A{{Ref_label|A|a|none}} | N/A | href="Taiwan" | |- 5 {{HKG}} N/A{{Ref_label|A|a|none}} | N/A | |} '''Notes{{Note|Notes}}''' {{refbegin}} * {{Note_label|A|a|none}} Statistics for 2014 unavailable. In 2010, the IFPI recorded total sales for Taiwan and Hong Kong at 56.3 and 37.8 million USD, respectively.{{cite web |url=http://www.riaj.or.jp/e/issue/pdf/RIAJ2012E.pdf|title=RIAJ: Yearbook 2012, IFPI 2010 Report: 31. Global Sales of Recorded Music by Country in 2010 (Page 24)|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of Japan]]|accessdate=2012-04-26}} {{refend}} == See also ==

page.title: National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/49.34.178.192|49.34.178.192]] ([[User talk:49.34.178.192|talk]]) to last version by Spontasia
revision.text:
{{coord|53|55|23|N|27|37|44|E|type:landmark_source:kolossus-frwiki|display=title}} {{Infobox Network |network_name = National State TV and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus
Нацыянальная дзяржаўная тэлерадыёкампанія Рэспублікі Беларусь |network_logo = [[File: BTRC (Belerus).png]] |country = Belarus |headquarters= Makayonka St. 9, [[Minsk]] |network_type = [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast]] [[radio]] and [[television]],
[[Website|online]] |available = National; International |owner = [[Government of Belarus]] |key_people = Ivan Eismont (Chairman){{cite web|title=Administration|url=https://www.tvr.by/eng/company/administration/|publisher=Belteleradiocompany|accessdate=14 February 2018|df=}} |launch_date = 15 November 1925 (Radio){{cite web|title=Radio Channels >> Belteleradiocompany|url=http://www.tvr.by/eng/radiomain.asp|publisher=Belteleradiocompany|accessdate=11 March 2014}}
1 January 1956 (Television){{cite web|title=TV Channels >> Television >> Belteleradiocompany|url=http://www.tvr.by/eng/tvmain.asp|publisher=Belteleradiocompany|accessdate=11 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415041010/http://www.tvr.by/eng/tvmain.asp|archivedate=15 April 2014|df=}} |founder = |slogan = |motto = |past_names = |website = http://www.tvr.by/ }} The '''National State TV and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus''' ({{lang-be|Нацыянальная дзяржаўная тэлерадыёкампанія Рэспублікі Беларусь}}, {{lang-ru|Национальная государственная телерадиокомпания Республики Беларусь}}) ('''Belteleradio''') is the state [[television]] and [[radio]] [[broadcasting]] service in [[Belarus]]. On 1 January 1993 it was admitted as a full active member of the [[European Broadcasting Union]] under the name '''Belarusian Television and Radio Company (BTRC)'''.{{cite web|title=EBU-UER / Active Members|url=http://www3.ebu.ch/members|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=11 March 2014}} [[Image:State TV Belarus.jpg|thumb|right|Broadcasting tower of the BTRC at 6 Kamunistychnaya st.]] == Television == Belteleradio operates six television channels, of which five are distributed nationally and one is distributed internationally.{{cite web|title=Тэлеканалы >> Тэлебачанне >> Белтэлерадыекампанiя|url=http://www.tvr.by/bel/tvmain.asp|publisher=Belteleradiocompany|accessdate=11 March 2014|language=Belarusian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528224643/http://www.tvr.by/bel/tvmain.asp|archivedate=28 May 2013|df=}} *[[Belarus 1]] – News, current affairs, and general interest programming *[[Belarus 2]] – Entertainment and sports programming *[[Belarus 3]] – Cultural programming, mostly broadcasts in [[Belarusian language]] *[[Belarus 4]] – Regional news, entertainment and cultural programming. Broadcasts separately for [[Brest, Belarus|Brest]], [[Vitebsk]], [[Gomel]], [[Grodno]], [[Minsk]] and [[Mogilev]] regions *[[Belarus 5]] – Sports channel *[[Belarus 24]] – International channel catering to viewers outside of Belarus *[[NTV Belarus]] – Belarusian version of [[NTV (Russia)|NTV Russia]]; programming consists of content from NTV Russia and other Russian channels{{cite web|title=NTV-Belarus >> Television >> Belteleradiocompany|url=http://www.tvr.by/eng/ntv.asp|publisher=Belteleradiocompany|accessdate=11 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415042349/http://www.tvr.by/eng/ntv.asp|archivedate=15 April 2014|df=}} == Radio == Belteleradio operates two national radio services and three regional [[FM Broadcasting|FM]] services. *[[First National Channel of Belarusian Radio|First Channel]] – The largest nationwide radio channel in Belarus *[[Radio Station "Belarus"]] – National and international service with programming in seven languages ([[Belarusian Language|Belarusian]], [[English Language|English]], [[French Language|French]], [[German Language|German]], [[Polish Language|Polish]], [[Russian Language|Russian]], and [[Spanish Language|Spanish]]){{cite web|title=About Radio {{!}} Radio Belarus|url=http://www.radiobelarus.tvr.by/en/content/about-radio|publisher=Belteleradiocompany|accessdate=11 March 2014}} *[[Channel "Culture"]] – Regional FM service, cultural and musical programming. *[[Radio "Stolitsa"]] – Regional FM service, local programming. *[[Radius-FM]] – Regional FM service, youth-oriented music station. ==Censorship and propaganda== ''See also [[Censorship in Belarus]]'' International experts and the Belarusian opposition traditionally name the state TV as one of the main instruments of [[propaganda]] by the authoritarian regime of [[Alexander Lukashenko]]. It is being accused of misinformation, advocating political repressions and rigging of elections, smearing regime critics.[http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2011/11/8/6740159/ Посол Польщі Генрик Літвін: Втратити добрий час – це великий ризик для України] - СЕРГІЙ ЛЕЩЕНКО, [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], 8 November 2011. Henryk Litwin, former ambassador of [[Poland]] to Belarus: "Television in Belarus is exclusively state propaganda"[http://www.edwardlucas.com/2017/01/20/belarus-propaganda/ Edward Lucas Podcast: Belarus propaganda] - 20.01.2017. [[Edward Lucas (journalist)|Edward Lucas]], editor at [[The Economist]]: “in Belarus the state television maintains Soviet levels of venom and mendacity.“ Employees and top managers of state TV channels, including channels of BTRC, have several times been subjects to sanctions from the [[EU]] and the [[United States]].[https://nn.by/?c=ar&i=61552 Поўны спіс 208 беларускіх чыноўнікаў, якім забаронены ўезд у ЕС] [Full list of 208 Belarusian officials banned from entering the EU] - [[Nasha Niva]], 11 October 2011 ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.tvr.by/eng/}} {{en icon}} * {{Official website|http://www.tvr.by/bel/}} {{be icon}} * {{Official website|http://www.tvr.by/rus/}} {{ru icon}} {{European Broadcasting Union Members}} {{Eastern Bloc media}} {{CATV Europe}} {{Telecommunications}} [[Category:Eastern Bloc media]] [[Category:Multilingual broadcasters|Belarus]] [[Category:Communications in Belarus]] [[Category:Television in Belarus]] [[Category:Censorship in Belarus]] [[Category:Propaganda in Belarus]] [[Category:European Broadcasting Union members]] [[Category:1956 establishments in Belarus]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1956]] {{Belarus-media-stub}}

{{about|the Neon Genesis Evangelion franchise|the TV anime series which began the franchise|Neon Genesis Evangelion}} {{italic title}} {{nihongo|'''''Neon Genesis Evangelion'''''|新世紀エヴァンゲリオン|Shin Seiki Evangerion}} is a Japanese [[media franchise]] created by [[Hideaki Anno]] and owned by [[Khara (studio)|Khara]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Bricken|first=Rob|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/the-original-evangelion-tv-series-is-finally-coming-to-1665689931|title=The Original Evangelion TV Series Is Finally Coming To Blu-Ray (io9)|publisher=[[Gizmodo|Gizmodo Media Group]]|date=December 12, 2014|accessdate=March 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://evangelion.co.jp/neon_genesis.html|title=新世紀エヴァンゲリオン|publisher=[[Khara (studio)|Khara, Inc.]]|accessdate=March 27, 2018}}</ref> Most of the franchise features an [[apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction|apocalyptic]] [[mecha]] action story, which revolves around the efforts by the [[paramilitary]] organization NERV to fight hostile beings called [[Angel (Neon Genesis Evangelion)|Angels]], using giant humanoids called [[Evangelion (mecha)|Evangelions]] that are piloted by select teenagers. Other works deviate from this theme to varying degrees, focusing more on romantic interactions between the characters, side stories which did not appear in the original works, and/or reimaginings of the conflicts from the original works.<ref>{{Cite web |title=「ヱヴァ」総監督 劇場で"緊急声明" |url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/entertainment/news/2007/02/12/02.html |work=Sponichi Annex |date=February 12, 2007 |accessdate=November 21, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070309002219/http://www.sponichi.co.jp/entertainment/news/2007/02/12/02.html |archivedate=March 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
The ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion (manga)|Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'' [[manga]] debuted in [[Shōnen Ace]] in December 1994, as a way to generate interest in the upcoming anime release. The ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion (anime)|Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'' anime was written and directed by [[Hideaki Anno]] and originally aired from October 1995 to March 1996. The show was groundbreaking, delving into religious, psychological and philosophical themes on an otherwise standard [[mecha]] backdrop. There was some debate over the controversial ending of the television series. In response, two films were made to provide an alternate ending for the show: ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Death & Rebirth]]'', released in March 1997, and ''[[The End of Evangelion]]'' released in July 1997. ''Death'' is a compilation of clips from the TV series, with some new footage added, and ''Rebirth'' comprises the first 30 minutes or so of ''End of Evangelion''.
The popularity of the show spawned numerous additional media, including video games, radio dramas, audio books, a novel, [[pachinko]] machines, and a [[tetralogy]] of films titled ''[[Rebuild of Evangelion]]''. Other derivative works include ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Angelic Days|Angelic Days]]'', ''[[Petit Eva: Evangelion@School]]'' and ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Campus Apocalypse|Campus Apocalypse]]''. As of June 2018, it is the 17th [[List of highest-grossing media franchises|highest-grossing franchise]] of all-time, with an estimated revenue of {{US$|14.9 billion|long=no}}.<ref>{{cite news |last=Peters |first=Megan |title='Pokemon' Is The Highest-Grossing Franchise Of All-Time |url=http://comicbook.com/anime/2018/06/24/pokemon-franchise-revenue-anime-media/ |accessdate=August 13, 2018 |work=ComicBook.com |date=June 23, 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
== Setting == Works within the ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' franchise typically have the same setting, characters and theme, but can vary in their portrayal of the storyline with alternate re-tellings of the original anime. ''Evangelion''{{'}}s fictional setting takes place after the Second Impact, a cataclysmic explosion in [[Antarctica]] which resulted in the deaths of billions and threw the Earth off its axis. Fifteen years after the Second Impact, a group of mysterious beings referred to as "[[Angel (Neon Genesis Evangelion)|Angels]]" begin appearing and pose a worldwide and existential threat to mankind. The NERV organization, a paramilitary special agency, is tasked with defeating the Angels, with the use of giant mechanical warriors known as "[[Evangelion (mecha)|Evangelions]]" to fight them. A select group of children pilot the Evangelions, with a focus on [[Shinji Ikari]], [[Rei Ayanami]] and [[Asuka Langley Soryu]].
The backdrop of ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' slowly reveals the true nature of Rei Ayanami, the Evangelions, the Angels, and the NERV and SEELE organizations. Religious themes, include [[Christianity]] and [[Kabbalah]] references to [[Adam]], [[Lilith]] and the [[Dead Sea Scrolls]]. The series is well known for its [[psychoanalysis]] of the characters, most heavily covered in the implementation of the Human Instrumentality Project, the secret goal of NERV and SEELE, whose result varies across different media, including the original anime, films, manga and video games.
== Anime == {{main|Neon Genesis Evangelion}} {{Nihongo|''Neon Genesis Evangelion''|新世紀エヴァンゲリオン|Shin Seiki Evangerion|literally "Gospel of a New Century"}}, commonly referred to as ''Evangelion'' or ''Eva'', is a Japanese [[Science fantasy|science-fantasy]] [[animation]] [[Television program|series]] that first [[Broadcasting|aired]] from October 1995 to March 1996. It was directed and written by [[Hideaki Anno]]. ''Evangelion'' follows [[Shinji Ikari]], a fourteen-year-old boy, who is summoned to Tokyo-3 by his father Gendo Ikari to pilot Evangelion Unit-01 on the eve of an Angel attack. Treated as a tool by his father, Shinji joins Rei Ayanami and Asuka Langley Soryu as mankind's last hope against the mysterious beings known as the "Angels". As the series progresses, the true natures of NERV, the Evangelions, and the Angels are revealed.
== OVA == ''[[Petit Eva: Evangelion@School]]'' is a [[super deformed]] parody [[OVA]] series that ran for 24 episodes as an adaptation of the ''Petit Eva'' and ''Petit Eva Bokura Tanken Dōkōkai'' manga. ''Petit Eva'' is a spin-off work that centers around high school life in a manner similar to ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Angelic Days]]''.
==Films==
===''Evangelion: Death and Rebirth''=== {{main|Evangelion: Death and Rebirth}} ''Death and Rebirth'', originally released on March 15, 1997, is a film that consists of a highly condensed character-based recap and re-edit of the episodes 1-24, titled ''Death'', and the first half of an unfinished new ending, titled ''Rebirth'', a retelling of episodes 25 and 26 of the television series as the events of the Human Instrumentality Project unfold from an external point of view.
=== ''The End of Evangelion'' === {{main|The End of Evangelion}} ''The End of Evangelion'', released on July 19, 1997, is the completed version of ''Rebirth'', an alternate version of the final episodes of the television series. SEELE attacks NERV, using their Mass Production Evangelion units, all in an attempt to complete the Human Instrumentality Project and initiate the Third Impact.
===''Rebuild of Evangelion''=== {{Main|Rebuild of Evangelion}} On September 9, 2006, Gainax confirmed a new animated film series called ''[[Rebuild of Evangelion]]'', consisting of four movies presenting an alternate retelling of the TV series (including new scenes, settings, and characters) and a completely new conclusion to the story.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.evangelion.co.jp/ | title = Rebuild of Evangelion | accessdate = 2006-09-12 | publisher = Gainax | date = 2006-09-10}}</ref> The first film [[Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone]] was released in Japan on September 1, 2007, with the [[Evangelion: 2.0 You Can (Not) Advance]] and [[Evangelion: 3.0 You Can (Not) Redo]] released on June 27, 2009 and November 17, 2012. The final film is slated for a 2020 release date.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.evangelion.co.jp/movie.html | title = Shin Evangelion Theatrical Trailer | accessdate = 2018-07-31 | publisher = Gainax | date = 2018-07-26}}</ref>
===Live-action film=== Development of a live-action movie version of ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' by [[Gainax]], [[Weta Workshop|Weta Workshop Ltd.]], and [[ADV Films]] (then the worldwide distributor of the ''Evangelion'' series outside of [[Asia]] and [[Australia]]) was announced at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] on May 21, 2003.<ref>{{cite web |title=Live Action Eva Press Release |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=21 May 2003 |accessdate=13 March 2012 |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2003-05-21/live-action-eva-press-release}}</ref> Early coverage included ADV Films raising "about half of the $100 million to $120 million needed to produce the film"<ref>{{cite web|last=Roth|first=Daniel|title=It's... Profitmón!|work=[[CNNMoney.com]]|publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=12 December 2005|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2005/12/12/8363101/index.htm|accessdate=22 February 2012}}</ref> and some concept art produced by [[Weta Workshop]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://features.cgsociety.org/story.php?story_id=1901 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051129033453/http://features.cgsociety.org/story.php?story_id=1901 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-11-29 |title=CGSociety - Neon Genesis Evangelion concept art from Weta |publisher=Features.cgsociety.org |date=2004-01-16 |accessdate=2012-11-21 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802225533/http://neon-genesis-evangelion.moviechronicles.com/2006-05/new-weta-workshop-concept-art/|archivedate=August 2, 2009|url=http://neon-genesis-evangelion.moviechronicles.com/2006-05/new-weta-workshop-concept-art/ |title=New Weta Workshop Concept Art|publisher=neon-genesis-evangelion.moviechronicles.com|author=Greg Broadmore|date=May 31, 2006|accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aintitcool.com/display.cgi?id=16790 |title=Ain't It Cool News: The best in movie, TV, DVD, and comic book news |publisher=Aintitcool.com |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref>
As time passed without any official announcements of production, the film project showed increasing signs of being in [[development hell]]. At [[Anime Expo]] 2008, ADV founders Matt Greenfield and John Ledford revealed that they had hired the producer [[John Woo]], pitched the idea to other producers such as [[Jerry Bruckheimer]] and [[Steven Spielberg]],<ref name="Jane And The Dragon Interview with Richard Taylor and Martin Baynton">[http://www.411mania.com/movies/columns/82079/The-Vile-One%5C%5Cs-Dungeon-8.07.08:-San-Diego-Comic-Con-2008---Jane-And-The-Dragon-Interview-with-Richard-Taylor-and-Martin-Baynton.htm Movies - The Vile One's Dungeon 8.07.08: San Diego Comic Con 2008 - Jane And The Dragon Interview with Richard Taylor and Martin Baynton]. 411mania.com (2011-05-02). Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> and seen increased interest in the wake of the success of the 2007 film ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]''.<ref name="ADV Panel at Anime Expo 2008">[http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/convention/2008/anime-expo/adv-films ADV Films - Anime Expo 2008]. Anime News Network (2011-12-14). Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> At [[Ohayocon]] 2009, Matt Greenfield announced that several U.S. studios were competing for final rights to the project, predicting an official announcement naming the studio, director, and perhaps casting information within the next nine months (he later noted that the closer he got to sealing a deal, the less he could say anything about it).<ref>[http://www.moviechronicles.com/neon-genesis-evangelion/ Evangelion Live Action Movie]. Movie Chronicles. Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> Though the sudden collapse and asset sale of [[A.D. Vision]] in September 2009 raised concerns over the project's viability, Greenfield, Ledford,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evageeks.org/2011/06/sunday-supanova-wrap-up/ |title=Sunday Supanova Wrap Up |publisher=EvaGeeks.org |date=2011-06-19 |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafire.com/?lzxrxuh30y646cj |title=Tiffany Grant & Matt Greenfield Sunday Supanova 2011.MP3 |publisher=Mediafire.com |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref> and producer Joseph Chou<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-02-04/producer/live-action-evangelion-project-still-active|title=Producer: Live-Action Evangelion Project Still Active|publisher=Anime News Network|date=February 4, 2010|accessdate=August 13, 2011}}</ref> insisted the project was still actively searching for a director (claiming delays owed more to the general deterioration of the American anime market than to ADV's internal issues).
In August 2011, Vision sued Gainax, claiming their refusal to accept an [[Option (filmmaking)|option]] payment for the perpetual live-action rights to ''Evangelion'' was a breach of contract and resulted in losing an opportunity to produce the film with a major studio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2011/08/12/ad-vision-inc-sues-gainax-co-ltd-over-live-action-evangelion-movie-agreement|title=A.D. Vision, Inc. sues Gainax Co., Ltd. over live-action Evangelion movie agreement|publisher=Crunchyroll|date=August 12, 2011|accessdate=August 13, 2011}}</ref> A.D. Vision has asked to be awarded the full live-action rights and any accruing [[English rule (attorney's fees)|legal fees]].
==Manga== {{main|Neon Genesis Evangelion (manga)}} {{see also|List of Neon Genesis Evangelion chapters}} A number of [[manga]] series based on the anime have been released, mostly notably the [[Neon Genesis Evangelion (manga)|official series]] by series character designer [[Yoshiyuki Sadamoto]], which was first serialized in February 1995 (eight months before the series' official premiere, in order to promote interest), and ended in November 2014, 19 years later. Three other manga have been created: ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Angelic Days]]'' by [[Fumino Hayashi]], ''[[Shinji Ikari Raising Project]]'' by Takahashi Osamu, and ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Campus Apocalypse]]'' by Min Min.
==Video games== {{further|List of Neon Genesis Evangelion video games}} ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' has spawned a number of video games. These range from action games such as [[Neon Genesis Evangelion (video game)|the same titled game]] for the [[Nintendo 64]] and [[Neon Genesis Evangelion 2|its sequel]] on the [[PlayStation 2]], the fighting game ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Battle Orchestra|Battle Orchestra]]'', the [[visual novel]]s ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Girlfriend of Steel|Girlfriend of Steel]]'' and ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion: Girlfriend of Steel 2|Girlfriend of Steel 2nd]]'', and the rhythm game ''3nd Impact'' (read "Sound Impact"). Characters from ''Evangelion'' also make numerous appearances in other titles such as in the ''[[Super Robot Wars]]'' series by [[Banpresto]]. The hit mobile game "Monster Strike", by the Japanese company Mixi, did a collaboration featuring dungeons and collectible units from the series.{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}}
==Other media== The ''Evangelion'' franchise has spread from the original anime into a number of different media, with some following the official [[Canon (fiction)|canon]] (of the 26-episode anime series and its three related films or the new ''Rebuild'' series) and others differing on important plot points originally introduced in the anime.
===Books=== * Newtype 100% Collection: A 1997 collection of ''[[Newtype]]''{{'}}s coverage of ''Evangelion'', particularly of artwork<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ex.org/2.3/28-newtype100.html |title=Newtype 100% Collection: Gundam W and Neon Genesis Evangelion |publisher=Ex.org |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120804050851/http://www.ex.org/2.3/28-newtype100.html |archivedate=2012-08-04 |df= }}</ref> * ''Death & Rebirth'' and ''End of Evangelion'' theatrical pamphlets: Limited edition supplementary booklets were distributed in Japanese theaters during the initial run of both ''[[Evangelion: Death and Rebirth]]'' and ''[[The End of Evangelion]]''. The latter pamphlet, nicknamed the "''[[Red Cross Book]]''" by overseas fans, contains descriptions and definitions of many areas and terms in the ''Evangelion'' storyline that the series left unclear. * ''Der Mond'' and ''Die Sterne'': Two German-titled [[art book]]s of the work of [[Yoshiyuki Sadamoto]], including concept art, character designs and renditions, and commentary about the Evangelion series. Both books also feature selections of Sadamoto's work on earlier and later works (such as ''[[Nadia (anime)|Nadia]]'', or [[Fatal Fury 2]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ex.org/news/1999_05.html |title=Press |publisher=EX |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001003100535/http://www.ex.org/news/1999_05.html |archivedate=2000-10-03 |df= }}</ref> * ''2015//The Last Year of Ryohji Kaji'': A limited edition, Japan-only publication by ''[[Newtype]]'' in 1997. The book is a combination photo/text book profiling the character of [[Ryōji Kaji]] through 16 mission "documents" left by him. The included letters, notes, and poems were written by [[Hiroshi Yamaguchi]] (a writer on the original TV series) and the photographs (including digitally-altered pictures of Evangelions, Angels, and other series-related objects) were taken by [[Ichiro Kamei]]. *''Groundwork of Evangelion'' is set of artbooks that contains production sketches. The first three cover the anime, with Volume 1 covering episode 1-8, Volume 2 covering 9-19, and Volume 3 covering 20-26. Groundwork of Evangelion The Movie 1 covers the first movie. ''Groundwork of Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone'' covers the first Rebuild film. Two volumes cover Groundwork Of Evangelion You Can (Not) Advance 2.0, the second Rebuild film. *''Neon Genesis Evangelion -ANIMA-'': A [[light novel]] series set in an alternate future diverging from the events of the anime.
===Dramas=== A parody [[Radio drama in Japan|radio drama]], ''Neon Genesis Evangelion – After the End'', was released in 1996 as part of the ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion Addition|NEON GENESIS EVANGELION ADDITION]]'' album. The story features the anime's original cast reuniting to star in a new Evangelion series, while attempting to change various themes of the series to make it more popular/accessible than it already is.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evamonkey.com/after-the-end/ |title=After the End - Eva Monkey, an Evangelion Fan Website |publisher=Evamonkey.com |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evamonkey.com/audio_drama_translation.htm |title="After the End" Audio Drama Translation by Matthew Grimes |publisher=Evamonkey.com |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=djGbkF5ncps&feature=related |title=Part 1 of Neon Genesis Evangelion - After the End Drama |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2010-12-15 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=91dBSPn8BF8&feature=related |title=Part 2 of Neon Genesis Evangelion - After the End Drama |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2010-12-16 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> A separate Evangelion audio cassette drama was released in 1996.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z2DFukevaCM</ref>
===Music=== {{main|Music of Neon Genesis Evangelion}} ''Evangelion'' has had numerous soundtrack releases since its debut on television, with most of the music composed by [[Shirō Sagisu]]. The television series' opening theme song "[[A Cruel Angel's Thesis]]" has become an iconic anime theme song. Four releases titled "Evangelion Classic", each one contained the classical music of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]], [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]], [[George Frideric Handel|Handel]], and [[Johann Sebastian Bach|J.S. Bach]] respectively.
===Pachinko=== A number of Evangelion-themed ''[[pachinko]]'' and ''[[pachisuro]]'' machines are offered at pachinko parlors: *[[:ja:CR新世紀エヴァンゲリオン|CR Neon Genesis Evangelion]] ''(Pachinko)''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fields.biz/catalog/cr_eva_r/ |title=エヴァンゲリオン 再起動プロジェクト |publisher=Fields.biz |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226195246/http://www.fields.biz/catalog/cr_eva_r/ |archivedate=2012-02-26 |df= }}</ref> *[[:ja:CR新世紀エヴァンゲリオン·セカンドインパクト|CR Neon Genesis Evangelion Second Impact]] ''(Pachinko)''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fields.biz/catalog/cr_eva_second/index.html |title=FIELDS_CRエヴァンゲリオンセカンドインパクト |publisher=Fields.biz |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206052646/http://www.fields.biz/catalog/cr_eva_second/index.html |archivedate=2012-02-06 |df= }}</ref> *[[:ja:新世紀エヴァンゲリオン (パチスロ)|Neon Genesis Evangelion]] ''(Pachisuro)'' *[[:ja:CR新世紀エヴァンゲリオン 〜奇跡の価値は〜|CR Neon Genesis Evangelion —Kiseki no Kachi wa—]] ''(Pachinko)''<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221060927/http://evaproject.jp/index2.html|archivedate=February 21, 2007|url=http://evaproject.jp/index2.html|title=Fields|publisher=evaproject.jp|accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref>
As of March 2018, ''Evangelion'' pachinko manufacturer Fields Corporation revealed that the ''Evangelion'' franchise has sold a total of 2.317{{nbsp}}million pachinko and pachislot machines, including 1.752{{nbsp}}million pachinko machines and 540,000 [[pachislot]] machines.<ref>{{cite book |title=Fact Book: Supplementary Financial Document for the Year Ended March 31, 2018 |date=May 11, 2018 |publisher=Fields Corporation |page=27 |url=http://www.fields.biz/ir/j/files/press/2018/press_20180511oe.pdf#page=27}}</ref> At an average unit price of $5,000,<ref>{{cite news |last=Graser |first=Marc |title=‘Dark Knight’ Producer Plays Pachinko to Launch Next Franchise (EXCLUSIVE) |url=https://variety.com/2013/digital/games/dark-knight-trilogy-producer-plays-pachinko-to-launch-next-franchise-1200571785/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=August 2, 2013}}</ref> the ''Evangelion'' franchise has grossed approximately {{US$|{{#expr:(2.317*5000)/1000}} billion|long=no}} from sales of pachinko and pachislot machines.
===Fanworks=== ''Evangelion'' is also popular among [[doujinshi]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunday featured mostly male-oriented (read, ecchi) works in anime and girl-get games. Favorites such as EVANGELION, SLAYERS, and TOKIMEKI MEMORIAL were out in full force|url=http://www.ex.org/3.6/14-event_comike.html|publisher=Ex.org|accessdate=2012-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120801145357/http://www.ex.org/3.6/14-event_comike.html|archivedate=2012-08-01|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Probably the two biggest titles were SHINSEIKI EVANGELION and Konami's TOKIMEKI MEMORIAL ~forever with you~. About 30-40% of the titles were ecchi.|url=http://www.ex.org/1.4/07-comike.html|publisher=Ex.org|accessdate=2012-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120731194632/http://www.ex.org/1.4/07-comike.html|archivedate=2012-07-31|df=}}</ref><ref>"It has been credited with defining gender roles, influencing attitudes toward the environment, and spawning the madly obsessive—and immensely profitable—otaku subculture embraced by tens of thousands of geeky fans who spend their lives unraveling the larger message of the show and collecting pornographic comic books featuring the show's female characters." "Let's Die Together", David Samuels, ''[[Atlantic Monthly]]''; May 2007, Vol. 299 Issue 4, p92-98, 7p</ref> inspiring notable titles such as "Evangelion RE-TAKE" (an unofficial sequel to the [[End of Evangelion]]) by Studio Kimigabuchi and even works by famous manga artists, such as "Birth of Evangelion" by [[Yun Kōga]].
===Amusement park=== On July 22, 2010, [[Fuji-Q Highland]] opened a 1,460m<sup>2</sup> section devoted to ''Evangelion'', featuring a lifesize entry plug and statue of [[Mari Makinami]],<ref>[http://www.kotaku.com.au/2011/04/neon-genesis-evangelions-most-illustrious-character-recreated/ Neon Genesis Evangelion’s Most Illustrious Character Recreated | Kotaku Australia]. Kotaku.com.au (2011-04-05). Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> an approximately 3-meter titanium Lance of Longinus,<ref>[http://gigazine.net/news/20110405_mari_evangelion_world_2nd/ 等身大の真希波・マリ・イラストリアスが「EVANGELION:WORLD 第二次計画」で富士急ハイランドに登場]. Gigazine. Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> NERV hallways with character cutouts<ref>[http://gigazine.net/news/20110405_eva_evangelion_world_2/ ネルフ本部が館内に出現、リニューアルされた「EVANGELION:WORLD」と実物大初号機]. Gigazine. Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> that lead to a hangar room with the 1:1 bust of [[Eva Unit-01]], SEELE monoliths, appropriate cosplay,<ref>[http://www.evageeks.org/2010/07/life-sized-evangelion-unit-01-completed/ Life-Sized Evangelion Unit-01 Completed]. EvaGeeks.org (2010-07-15). Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://afufu.net/freewill/2010/07/life-size-evangelion-final-video-and-images/ |title=Afufu.net |publisher=Afufu.net |accessdate=2012-11-21 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Eva-themed hotel rooms,<ref>[http://gigazine.net/news/20110406_eva_room_evangelion_world_2nd/ 綾波レイをフィーチャーした富士急ハイランドの「EVANGELION:ROOM」を見せてもらった]. Gigazine. Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> and food products.<ref>[http://www.gigazine.net/news/20110406_goods_evangelion_world_2nd/ 「ゼーレ、チョコクランチの座」など、富士急「EVANGELION:WORLD」のエヴァンゲリオンストアのお土産試食レビュー]. Gigazine. Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref> A bust of [[Eva Unit-02]] modeled after a scene in ''Evangelion: 2.0'' was installed in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://neweva.blog103.fc2.com/blog-entry-1120.html |title=富士急ハイランドに実物大エヴァ2号機ザ・ビースト登場！ : みんなのエヴァンゲリオン(ヱヴァ)ファン |publisher=Neweva.blog103.fc2.com |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fujiq.jp/eva/second/index.html |title=富士急ハイランド｜エヴァンゲリオン 実物大初号機建造計画 |publisher=Fujiq.jp |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highlandresort.co.jp/guestroom/roomtype/eva.php |title=エヴァンゲリオン ルームでエヴァの世界を体感せよ！｜ハイランドリゾート ホテル＆スパ |publisher=Highlandresort.co.jp |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2011-01-26/life-size-eva-02-head-evangelion-hotel-room-planned |title=Life-Size EVA-02 Head, Evangelion Hotel Room Planned - Interest |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2012-11-17 |accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref><ref>[http://www.jpbeta.net/2011/04/eva02_evangelion_world_2nd/ 「EVANGELION：WORLD」第二次计划启动，继初号机之后等身大二号机实体诞生。 « JPbeta 多元化日本文化资讯站]. Jpbeta.net. Retrieved on 2011-12-18.</ref><ref>[http://gigazine.net/news/20110405_eva02_evangelion_world_2nd/ 富士急ハイランドに姿を現した「ザ・ビースト」モードのエヴァ2号機]. Gigazine. Retrieved on 2011-12-18</ref>
===Crossovers===
=====[[Transformers]]===== {{main|Transformers x Evangelion}}
A Transformers x Evangelion comic and toy line featured a Transformers and Evangelion crossover.<ref>https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2014-04-24/takara-tomy-planning-transformers-x-evangelion-crossover</ref><ref>https://tfwiki.net/wiki/Transformers_×_Evangelion</ref>

[[Category:Neon Genesis Evangelion| ]] [[Category:Gainax]] [[Category:Impact events in fiction]] [[Category:Kaiju]] [[Category:Mecha anime and manga]] [[Category:Mecha]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:Mythology in popular culture]] [[Category:Fiction about religion]] [[Category:Science fiction anime and manga]] [[Category:Tatsunoko Production]]

William B. Fosser's puppet production '''Opera in Focus''' is a troupe which performs [[opera]] and [[musical theater]] with some of the world's most sophisticated puppets. The Opera in Focus puppet opera theater is located in [[Rolling Meadows, Illinois]].
==History== Fosser, a puppeteer and artistic director of the legendary Kungsholm Miniature Opera in [[Chicago]], began designing the puppets that would eventually be used in his Opera in Focus productions in the late 1930s. The cost involved in building each elaborately articulated puppet prevented him from constructing them until 1956. He presented the first Opera in Focus performances—by invitation only—in 1958 in a rented store on the [[neighborhoods of Chicago|north side of Chicago]], where they were received with great enthusiasm. [[File:244.x600.class.puppetopera.open.jpg|thumb |alt=Opera In Focus |Pagliacci]]
In order to support the puppet opera, Fosser made a living as a [[set designer]] and [[art director]] in the motion picture industry, working on such films as ''[[Ordinary People]]'', ''[[Home Alone]]'', ''[[Backdraft (film)|Backdraft]]'', ''[[Weird Science (film)|Weird Science]]'', ''[[Music Box (film)|Music Box]]'', ''[[Damien: Omen II]]'', ''[[The Breakfast Club]]'', ''[[A League of Their Own]]'' and ''[[Groundhog Day (film)|Groundhog Day]]''. He also worked as a set designer for live theatrical productions, designing scenery for the [[Lyric Opera of Chicago]], as well as the Candlelight, Ivanhoe, and Drury Lane theaters. He spent his free time further developing and perfecting his puppets and the presentation of his elaborate miniature operatic productions. Due to the hectic nature of his career in the film industry, performances of Opera in Focus were infrequent, except for periods in 1962-1963 and 1978-1979 when Opera in Focus enjoyed residencies in Detroit and at the now-defunct Magic Pan restaurant in Chicago.
In 1993 the Rolling Meadows Chamber of Commerce offered Fosser a permanent home in [[Rolling Meadows, Illinois]], where Opera in Focus has been performed weekly ever since.<ref>[http://www.toytheatre.info/Network/Fosser/Review02/Review02.htm Puppet Love: Bill Fosser's Quest to Keep Miniature Opera Alive]</ref><ref>[http://www.lib.niu.edu/ipo/1995/ip950530.html article in ''Illinois Parks & Recreation'', May/June 1995]</ref>
In 2005 Fosser received the President's Award from the Puppeteers of America. Opera in Focus has received a number of awards including the prestigious Dorothy Mullen Award from the National Parks and Recreation Association for Fine Arts Programming.
William Fosser died of congestive heart failure and pneumonia on February 19, 2006, in Resurrection Hospital, in Chicago. He was buried at [[Queen of Heaven Cemetery]] in [[Hillside, Illinois]].<ref>[http://toytheatre.info/Memories/Fosser/obit206.html Fosser's Obituary]</ref>
The theater continues to present a stunning sampling of fully staged scenes from well-known operas & musicals. Each hour-long performance may offer between three and five scenes, depending on the length of the individual segments. A narration of the action by the well-known actor, Tony Mockus, precedes each scene. The 16" puppets are manipulated from below the stage floor and are capable of very lifelike action and dramatic gestures for which opera singers are so famous.
A demonstration of the puppet operation and a tour of the highly technical backstage area follow each performance. Despite the small stage (only five feet wide and two feet deep), the illusion of live opera prevails. The puppet opera performances are capable of charming a wide range of audiences - from the lovers of opera and musical theater to those simply fascinated by the fine art of puppetry.
==See also== * [[Puppetry]] * [[Opera]] * [[Phantom of the Opera]] * [[Madame Butterfly]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
