{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox album | name = The Berlin Tapes | type = soundtrack | artist = [[Iva Davies]] & [[Icehouse (band)|Icehouse]] | cover = TheBerlinTapesIcehouse01.jpg | alt = | released = AUS: October 1995
JAP: 1996 | recorded = | venue = | studio = dIVA Studios, [[Whale Beach, New South Wales|Whale Beach]], Australia | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | length = 46:09 Original single CD release | label = dIVA/Massive/For Life | producer = [[Iva Davies]] | prev_title = [[Full Circle (Icehouse album)|Full Circle]] | prev_year = 1994 | next_title = [[The Singles (Icehouse album)|The Singles]] | next_year = 1996 | misc = {{Singles | name = The Berlin Tapes | type = soundtrack | single1 = Heaven | single1date = September 1995 | single2 = Complicated Game | single2date = February 1996 }} }} {{Infobox album | name = Heroes | type = soundtrack | artist = [[Icehouse (band)|Icehouse]] | cover = HeroesIcehouse2004_01.jpg | alt = | released = 16 August 2004 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Rock (music)|Rock]] | length = | label = Diva / [[Warner Music Australia|Warner]] | producer = [[Iva Davies]] | prev_title = [[Meltdown (Icehouse album)|Meltdown]] | prev_year = 2002 | next_title = [[White Heat: 30 Hits]] | next_year = 2011 | misc = {{Singles | name = Heroes | type = soundtrack | single1 = Heroes | single1date = 16 August 2004 }} }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] (2002) | rev1Score = {{Rating|2.5|5}}{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r622669|pure_url=yes}} }} '''''The Berlin Tapes''''' is a [[Cover version|covers]] / [[soundtrack]] album by [[Australia]]n rock musician [[Iva Davies]] and his band [[Icehouse (band)|Icehouse]]. The record was a collaboration between Davies and classical music composer [[Max Lambert]] to accompany the [[Sydney Dance Company]]'s production of the ballet ''Berlin'', for which Icehouse performed live on stage. The covers are mostly [[Acoustic music|acoustic]], with [[piano]], [[String instrument|strings]] and subtle [[electronica]] incorporated into most tracks. The record was initially released as a single or double disc set, with the second disc consisting of instrumental Icehouse tracks performed with the ballet. A 1996 [[Japan]]ese re-release included three bonus tracks; a 2002 digitally remastered version with five bonus tracks was released in Australia – this time credited simply to ''Icehouse''.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r622669|pure_url=yes}} |title=''The Berlin Tapes'' (2002) Review |publisher=[[Allmusic|allmusic guide]] |accessdate=2008-07-07 }} It was re-released in Australia in August 2004 and re-titled as '''''[[Heroes (Icehouse album)|Heroes]]''''' (see second infobox at below right),{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r949656|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Heroes'' (2004) Review |publisher=[[Allmusic|allmusic guide]] |accessdate=2008-07-12 }} coinciding with [[Seven Network]]'s TV broadcast of the [[2004 Summer Olympics|Athens Olympic Games]], which had two tracks removed and a second mix of "Heroes" added. "[[Heroes (David Bowie song)|Heroes]]" (The Athens Mix), a cover of [[David Bowie]]'s original hit, was released in August 2004 and peaked at #93 on the Australian singles charts.{{cite web |title = australian-charts.com – Icehouse |publisher = australian-charts.com |url = http://www.australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Icehouse |accessdate = 2008-07-09 }} ==Track listing== ===Australian 1995 release=== # "[[Loving the Alien]]" ([[David Bowie]]) – 5:34 # "[[Sister Europe]]" ([[The Psychedelic Furs]]) – 3:59 # "[[Heaven (Talking Heads song)|Heaven]]" ([[Talking Heads]]) – 4:27 # "[[Drums and Wires|Complicated Game]]" ([[XTC]]) – 5:27 # "Berlin" ([[Lou Reed]]) – 0:49 # "[[All the Way (Frank Sinatra song)|All the Way]]" ([[Frank Sinatra]]) – 3:16 # "[[All Tomorrow's Parties]]" ([[The Velvet Underground]]) – 4:35 # "[[Let There Be Love (Simple Minds song)|Let There Be Love]]" ([[Simple Minds]]) – 4:33 # "Disappointed" ([[Public Image Ltd]]) – 5:26 # "A Really Good Time" ([[Roxy Music]]) – 3:23 # "At Night" ([[The Cure]]) – 3:57 # "[[Love Like Blood (song)|Love Like Blood]]" ([[Killing Joke]]) – 5:47 # "[[Heroes (David Bowie song)|Heroes]]" ([[David Bowie]]) – 4:29 ===Australian 2CD release #1=== '''Disc One – The Berlin Tapes''' *Disc One track listing is identical to single CD issue. '''Disc Two – [[Boxes (Icehouse album)|Boxes]]''' # "Early Images" – 3:48 # "Terra Incognita" – 1:47 # "Solitaire" – 4:22 # "A Break In The Clouds" – 4:14 # "Love Dance" – 2:57 # "No Promises" – 6:02 # "The Tempest – Part One" – 2:20 # "The Tempest – Part Two" – 2:27 # "Gravity" – 1:40 # "Indian Summer" – 3:45 # "Russian Dolls" – 5:13 # "Regular Boys" – 2:37 # "Familiar Winds" – 2:01 # "The Walker" – 1:25 # "No Promises (Reprise)" – 1:21 # "Surgery" – 2:36 # "Regular Boys (Reprise)" – 3:17 # "Labyrinth – Part One" – 1:20 # "Labyrinth – Part Two" – 1:00 # "Liberation – Part One" – 1:23 # "Liberation – Part Two" – 1:55 [Liner Notes: Music by Iva Davies and Bob Kretschmer. Boxes is a commission for the Sydney Dance Company. It was conceived by its composers, in collaboration with choreographer Graeme Murphy as a dance work. The first live performance of 'Boxes' was given by the Sydney Dance Company together with Iva Davies, Bob Kretschmer, Masaki Tanazawa in the Opera Theatre of the Sydney Opera House on 7 November 1985.] ===Australian 2CD release #2=== '''Disc One – The Berlin Tapes''' *Disc One track listing is identical to single CD issue. '''Disc Two''' # "Dedicated to Glam" # "Melt Steel Part 1" # "Orbital Line" # "Melt Steel Part 2" # "Pas de Trois" – 4:46 # "Giant and Child Fugue" – 2:15 # "Melt Steel Part 3" # "Crazy (Midnight Mix)" '''Note''' *Disc Two tracks are not covers, but new versions of songs originally by Icehouse] ===Japanese 1996 release=== Track listing for 1-13 is identical to single CD issue. {{track listing | collapsed = no | headline = Japanese 1996 release bonus tracks | title14 = Be My Friend | note14 = [[Free (band)|Free]] | length14 = 4:04 | title15 = Being Boiled | note15 = [[The Human League]] | length15 = 4:24 | title16 = Blank Frank | note16 = [[Brian Eno]] | length16 = 3:37 | title17 = How Do You Sleep? | note17 = [[John Lennon]] | length17 = 8:02 }} ===Australian 2002 reissue=== Track listing for 1-13 is identical to original single CD issue. {{track listing | collapsed = no | headline = Australian 2002 reissue bonus tracks | title14 = Be My Friend | note14 = [[Free (band)|Free]] | length14 = 4:04 | title15 = Being Boiled | note15 = [[The Human League]] | length15 = 4:24 | title16 = How Do You Sleep? | note16 = [[John Lennon]] | length16 = 8:02 | title17 = Giant and Child Fugue | note17 = Icehouse original | length17 = 2:15 | title18 = Pas de Trois | note18 = Icehouse original | length18 = 4:46 }} '''Notes''' *Tracks 14-16 originally appeared on the Japanese issue of ''The Berlin Tapes''. *Tracks 17-18 originally appeared on the second 2-CD issue of ''The Berlin Tapes''. ===Australian 2004 release as ''Heroes''=== This version drops "Disappointed" and "At Night" from the original track listing, and adds a new mix of "Heroes". # "[[Heroes (David Bowie song)|Heroes]]" (The Berlin Mix) ([[David Bowie]]) # "Loving the Alien" ([[David Bowie]]) # "Sister Europe" ([[The Psychedelic Furs]]) # "Heaven" ([[Talking Heads]]) # "Complicated Game" ([[XTC]]) # "Berlin" ([[Lou Reed]]) # "All the Way" ([[Frank Sinatra]]) # "All Tomorrow's Parties" ([[The Velvet Underground]]) # "Let There Be Love" ([[Simple Minds]]) # "Really Good Time" ([[Roxy Music]]) # "[[Love Like Blood (song)|Love Like Blood]]" ([[Killing Joke]]) # "Heroes" (The Athens Mix) ([[David Bowie]]) ===Australian 2012 reissue=== This version adds the additional tracks from the 2002 reissue (minus [[Being Boiled]]), plus the Athens Mix of [[Heroes (David Bowie song)|Heroes]] from the 2004 release of the same name. Track listing for 1-13 is identical to original single CD issue. {{track listing | collapsed = no | headline = Australian 2012 reissue bonus tracks | title14 = Be My Friend | note14 = [[Free (band)|Free]] | length14 = 4:04 | title15 = How Do You Sleep? | note15 = [[John Lennon]] | length15 = 8:02 | title16 = Giant and Child Fugue | note16 = Icehouse original | length16 = 2:15 | title17 = Pas de Trois | note17 = Icehouse original | length17 = 4:46 | title18 = Heroes (The Athens Mix) | note18 = [[David Bowie]] | length18 = 3:54 }} ==Personnel== Adapted from AllMusic.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r622669|pure_url=yes}} |title=''The Berlin Tapes'' (bonus tracks) credits |publisher=[[Allmusic|allmusic guide]] |accessdate=2008-07-07 }}{{cite web | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130929120725/http://hem.passagen.se/honga/database/i/icehouse.html | url = http://hem.passagen.se/honga/database/i/icehouse.html | title = The Flowers / Icehouse | last1 = Holmgren | first1 = Magnus | publisher = [[Australian Rock Database]]. Passagen.se (Magnus Holmgren) | archivedate = 29 September 2013 | accessdate = 21 March 2014 }} *Greg Barrett – photography *Cover photo of Katherine Griffiths, Sydney Dance Company *Don Bartley – mastering *Steve Bull – [[bass guitar]] *David Chapman – arranger, programming, engineer *Iva Davies – [[Acoustic guitar|guitar (acoustic)]], bass, [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]], programming, [[vocals]], engineer, digital remastering (2002), *Bruce Elder – liner notes *Simon Leadley – engineer *Ryan Scott – digital remastering (2002 version) *Adrian Wallis – [[cello]] *Paul Wheeler – [[Drum kit|drums]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Icehouse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Berlin Tapes, The}} [[Category:Icehouse (band) albums]] [[Category:1995 soundtracks]] [[Category:Theatre soundtracks]]

page.title: The Cycles: International Grand Prix Racing

revision.comment: /* top */removing deprecated parameters from [[Template:infobox video game]] - [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests_for_approval/PrimeBOT_18|BRFA]]
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox video game |title = The Cycles: International Grand Prix Racing |collapsible = |state = |image = |caption = Title screen |developer = [[Distinctive Software]] |publisher = [[Accolade (company)|Accolade]] |series = |engine = |released = 1989 |genre = [[Racing video game|Racing]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[Amiga]], [[Commodore 64|C64]], [[MS-DOS]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[ZX Spectrum]] |director = |producer = Pam Levins |designer = Brad Gour, [[Don Mattrick]] |artist = John Boechler, Michael Smith |writer = |composer = Krisjan Hatlield }} '''''The Cycles: International Grand Prix Racing''''' is a [[1989 in video gaming|1989]] [[computer game]] [[video game developer|developed]] by [[Distinctive Software]] and [[video game publisher|published]] by [[Accolade (company)|Accolade]]. It has similarities to ''[[Grand Prix Circuit (game)|Grand Prix Circuit]]'', except it is a [[motorcycle]] [[Racing video game|racing sim]]. The game includes all the tracks of [[1989 Grand Prix motorcycle racing season]]. Laguna Seca and Goiania circuits are not available when you choose 125cc bike.
It was released for the [[Amiga]], [[Commodore 64]], [[MS-DOS]], [[Amstrad CPC]] and [[ZX Spectrum]].
==How to play== More like a simulation than an [[arcade game]], unlike [[Sega]]'s ''[[Hang-On]]'' and ''[[Super Hang-On]]'', the player has no time limit to clear races. If the player crashes, they're out of the race. To win each race, the player must get through the finish lines. The player can change the number of laps for a race.
The game has several modes which it can be played in:
*Championship: Choose a bike, not a track. If the player is qualified for race, he can proceed to it. *Practice: The player chooses their bike and track. *Single Race: Player chooses a bike and track. If the player is qualified for race, he can proceed to it.
==External links== *{{moby game|id=/cycles-international-grand-prix-racing|name=''The Cycles: International Grand Prix Racing''}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cycles: International Grand Prix Racing}} [[Category:1989 video games]] [[Category:Amiga games]] [[Category:Commodore 64 games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:Amstrad CPC games]] [[Category:ZX Spectrum games]] [[Category:Racing video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]]
{{racing-videogame-stub}}

page.title: The Man with the Golden Gun (film)

revision.text:
{{Other uses|The Man with the Golden Gun (disambiguation){{!}}The Man with the Golden Gun}} {{EngvarB|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = The Man with the Golden Gun | image = The Man with the Golden Gun - UK cinema poster.jpg | border = yes | caption = British cinema poster for ''The Man with the Golden Gun'', designed by [[Robert McGinnis]] |alt= A man in a dinner jacket holding a pistol is in the centre of the picture. Various scenes and images surround him, including two women in bikinis, a midget with a pistol, a car stunt and explosions. At the bottom right, oversized and pointing towards the man in the dinner jacket, is a golden gun, with a hand holding a bullet, about to load the gun. The top of the picture has the words "ROGER MOORE as JAMES BOND 007". At the bottom are the words "THE MAN WITH THE GOLDEN GUN". | starring = [[Roger Moore]]
[[Christopher Lee]]
[[Britt Ekland]]
[[Maud Adams]] | screenplay = [[Richard Maibaum]]
[[Tom Mankiewicz]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[The Man with the Golden Gun (novel)|The Man with the Golden Gun]]''|[[Ian Fleming]]}} | cinematography = [[Ted Moore]]
[[Oswald Morris]] | director = [[Guy Hamilton]] | producer = [[Albert R. Broccoli]]
[[Harry Saltzman]] | music = [[John Barry (composer)|John Barry]] | editing = [[Raymond Poulton]]
John Shirley | studio = [[Eon Productions]] | distributor = [[United Artists]] | released = {{Film date|1974|12|19|df=y|London, premiere}} | runtime = 125 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English
Thai | budget = $7 million | gross = $97.6 million }} '''''The Man with the Golden Gun''''' is a 1974 British [[spy film]], the ninth in the [[James Bond in film|''James Bond'' series]] produced by [[Eon Productions]], and the second to star [[Roger Moore]] as the fictional [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] agent [[James Bond (literary character)|James Bond]]. A loose adaptation of [[Ian Fleming]]'s [[The Man with the Golden Gun (novel)|novel of the same name]], the film has Bond sent after the Solex Agitator, a device that can harness the [[solar power|power of the sun]], while facing the assassin [[Francisco Scaramanga]], the "Man with the Golden Gun". The action culminates in a duel between them that settles the fate of the Solex. ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' was the fourth and final film in the series directed by [[Guy Hamilton]]. The script was written by [[Richard Maibaum]] and [[Tom Mankiewicz]]. The film was set in the face of the [[1973 oil crisis|1973 energy crisis]], a dominant theme in the script. Britain had still not yet fully overcome the crisis when the film was released in December 1974. The film also reflects the then popular [[martial arts film]] craze, with several [[kung fu]] scenes and a predominantly Asian location, being set and shot in [[Thailand]], [[Hong Kong]], and [[Macau]]. Part of the film is also set in [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]], but it was not shot there. The film was met with mixed reviews, and some critics described it as the lowest point in the canon up to that time. [[Christopher Lee]]'s portrayal of Scaramanga as a villain of similar skill and ability to Bond was generally praised, but reviewers criticized the film as a whole, particularly its comedic approach and the performances of Moore and [[Britt Ekland]]. Although the film was profitable, it is the fourth lowest grossing film in the series. It was also the last film to be co-produced by [[Albert R. Broccoli]] and [[Harry Saltzman]], with Saltzman selling his 50% stake in [[Danjaq, LLC]], the parent company of Eon Productions, after the release of the film. ==Plot== In London, a golden bullet with James Bond's code "007" etched into its surface is received by [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]]. It is believed that it was sent by the famed assassin [[Francisco Scaramanga]], who uses a golden gun, to intimidate the agent. Because of the perceived threat to the agent's life, [[M (James Bond)|M]] relieves Bond of a mission revolving around the work of the solar energy scientist named Gibson, thought to be in possession of information crucial to solving the [[1973 energy crisis|energy crisis]] with [[solar power]]. Bond sets out unofficially to locate Scaramanga. After retrieving a spent golden bullet from a belly dancer in [[Beirut]] and tracking its manufacturer to [[Macau]], Bond encounters Andrea Anders, Scaramanga's mistress, collecting the shipment of golden bullets at a [[casino]]. Bond follows her to Hong Kong and, in her [[The Peninsula Hong Kong|Peninsula Hotel]] room, pressures Anders to expose information about Scaramanga, his appearance and his plans; she directs him to the [[Bottoms Up Club]]. The club proves to be the location of Scaramanga's next [[contract killing|hit]], Gibson, from whom Scaramanga's [[dwarfism|dwarf]] henchman Nick Nack steals the "Solex agitator", a key component of a [[Power station#Solar|solar power station]]. Before Bond can assert his innocence in Gibson's death, he is taken away by Lieutenant Hip and transported to meet M and [[Q (James Bond)|Q]] in a hidden headquarters in the wreck of the {{RMS|Queen Elizabeth}} in the harbour. M assigns Bond to retrieve the Solex. Bond then travels to [[Bangkok]] to meet Hai Fat, a wealthy Siamese entrepreneur suspected of arranging Gibson's murder. Bond poses as Scaramanga, but his plan backfires because unbeknown to him, Scaramanga himself is operating at Hai Fat's estate. Bond is captured and placed in Fat's martial arts academy, where the students are instructed to kill him. After escaping with the aid of Hip and his nieces, Bond speeds away on a motorized sampan along the river and reunites with his assistant, Mary Goodnight. Scaramanga subsequently kills Hai Fat and assumes control of his empire, taking the Solex with him. Anders visits Bond, revealing that she sent the bullet to London and wants Bond to kill Scaramanga. In payment, she promises to hand the Solex over to him at a [[Muay Thai]] venue the next day. At the match, Bond discovers Anders dead and meets Scaramanga. Bond observes the Solex on the floor and is able to smuggle it away to Hip, who passes it to Goodnight. When Goodnight attempts to place a [[homing device]] on Scaramanga's car, she becomes trapped in the trunk. Bond discovers Scaramanga driving off and steals an [[American Motors|AMC]] showroom car to give chase, coincidentally with vacationing [[Sheriff J.W. Pepper]] seated within it. Bond and Pepper follow Scaramanga in a car chase across Bangkok, which concludes when Scaramanga's car transforms into a plane, which flies himself, Nick Nack and Goodnight away from Bond. Picking up Goodnight's tracking signal, Bond flies a seaplane into [[People's Republic of China|Red Chinese]] waters and lands at [[Ko Tapu|Scaramanga's island]]. Scaramanga welcomes and shows Bond the solar power plant operation that he has taken over, the technology for which he intends to sell to the highest bidder. While demonstrating the equipment, Scaramanga uses a powerful energy beam to destroy Bond's plane. Scaramanga then proposes a pistol [[duel]] with Bond on the beach; the two men stand back to back and are officiated by Nick Nack to take twenty paces, but when Bond turns and fires, Scaramanga has vanished. Nick Nack leads Bond into Scaramanga's Funhouse where Bond stands in the place of a mannequin of himself; when Scaramanga walks by, Bond outwits and kills him. Goodnight kills Scaramanga's security chief Kra, sending his body into one of the temperature control vats. His body heat raises the temperature of the helium cooling the solar plant, which begins to spiral out of control. Bond retrieves the Solex unit just before the island is destroyed, and they escape unharmed in Scaramanga's [[Junk (ship)|Chinese junk]]. Bond then fends off a final attack by Nick Nack, who smuggled himself aboard, placing Nick Nack in a wicker basket on the mainmast of the ship. Bond and Goodnight celebrate their mission by romancing each other. ==Cast== * [[Roger Moore]] as [[James Bond filmography|James Bond]]: An MI6 agent who receives a golden bullet, supposedly from Scaramanga, indicating that he is a target of Scaramanga. * [[Christopher Lee]] as [[Francisco Scaramanga#Film biography|Francisco Scaramanga]]: The main villain and assassin who is identified by his use of a golden gun; he also has a 'superfluous papilla', or [[supernumerary nipple]]. Scaramanga plans to misuse solar energy for destructive purposes. Lee was Ian Fleming's step-cousin{{cite web|last=Brooke|first=Michael|title=The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/film/id/505543/|work=BFI Screenonline|publisher=The [[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=27 July 2011}} and regular golf partner.{{cite news|last=Higgins|first=John|title=From scaremonger to Scaramanga|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=12 December 1974}} Scaramanga has been called "the best-characterised Bond villain yet."{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=118}} * [[Britt Ekland]] as [[Mary Goodnight]]: Bond's assistant. Described by the critic of the ''[[Sunday Mirror]]'' as being "an astoundingly stupid blonde British agent".{{cite news|title=Amazing, Mr Bond, but you're still a winner|newspaper=[[Sunday Mirror]]|date=22 December 1974}} Ekland had previously been married to [[Peter Sellers]], who appeared in the 1967 Bond film ''[[Casino Royale (1967 film)|Casino Royale]]''.{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=134}} * [[Maud Adams]] as [[List of henchmen of James Bond villains#The Man with the Golden Gun|Andrea Anders]]: Scaramanga's mistress. Adams described the role as "a woman without a lot of choices: she's under the influence of this very rich, strong man, and is fearing for her life most of the time; and when she actually rebels against him and defects is a major step."{{cite video|people=Maud Adams|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' was the first of three Bond films in which Maud Adams appeared; she played a different character, [[Octopussy]], in the 1983 [[Octopussy|film of the same name]], and would later have a cameo as an extra in Roger Moore's last Bond film, ''A View to a Kill''.{{cite video|people=[[Maud Adams]] |title=Inside A View to a Kill |medium=VCD/DVD |publisher=MGM Home Entertainment Inc}} * [[Hervé Villechaize]] as [[List of henchmen of James Bond villains#The Man with the Golden Gun|Nick Nack]]: Scaramanga's dwarf manservant and accomplice. Villechaize was later known to television audiences as Tattoo in the series ''[[Fantasy Island (1977 TV series)|Fantasy Island]]''. * [[Richard Loo]] as Hai Fat: A Thai millionaire industrialist who was employing Scaramanga to assassinate the inventor of the "Solex" (a revolutionary solar energy device) and steal the device. He himself is later killed by Scaramanga. * [[Soon-Tek Oh]] as Lieutenant Hip: Bond's local contact in Hong Kong and Bangkok. Soon-Tek Oh trained in martial arts for the role,{{cite video|title=Double-O Stuntmen|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 2|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} and his voice was partially dubbed over.{{cite video|people=Soon-Tek Oh|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} * [[Clifton James]] as Sheriff J.W. Pepper: A Louisiana sheriff who happens to be on holiday in Thailand. Hamilton liked Pepper in the previous film, [[Live and Let Die (film)|''Live and Let Die'']], and asked Mankewicz to write him into ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' as well. * [[Bernard Lee]] as [[M (James Bond)|M]]: The head of MI6. * [[Marc Lawrence]] as Rodney: An American gangster who attempts to outshoot Scaramanga in his funhouse, and loses, being shot in the head by Scaramanga. Lawrence also appeared in ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]''.{{cite web|title=Diamonds Are Forever (1971)|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/film/id/505509/credits.html|work=BFI Screenonline|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=9 August 2011}} * [[Desmond Llewelyn]] as [[Q (James Bond)|Q]]: The head of MI6's technical department. * [[Marne Maitland]] as Lazar: A Portuguese gunsmith based in Macau who manufactures golden bullets for Scaramanga. * [[Lois Maxwell]] as [[Miss Moneypenny]], M's secretary. * [[James Cossins]] as Colthorpe: An MI6 armaments expert who identifies the maker of Scaramanga's golden bullets. The first draft of the script originally called the role Boothroyd until it was realised that was also Q's name and it was subsequently changed.{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=131}} * [[Carmen du Sautoy]] as Saida: A Beirut belly dancer. Saida was originally written as overweight and wearing excessive make-up, but the producers decided to cast a woman closer to the classic [[Bond girl]]. * [[Francoise Therry]] as Chew Mee, Hai Fat's mistress, whom Bond memorably finds swimming nude in a swimming pool. ==Production== [[Albert R. Broccoli]] and [[Harry Saltzman]] intended to follow ''[[You Only Live Twice (film)|You Only Live Twice]]'' with ''The Man with the Golden Gun'', inviting Roger Moore to the Bond role. However, filming was planned in Cambodia, and the [[Samlaut Uprising]] made filming impractical, leading to the production being cancelled.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=82}} ''[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service (film)|On Her Majesty's Secret Service]]'' was produced instead with [[George Lazenby]] as Bond. Lazenby's next Bond film, Saltzman told a reporter, would be either ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' or ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]''. The producers chose the latter title, with Sean Connery returning as Bond.{{cite news|last=Graham|first=Sheilah|authorlink=Sheilah Graham Westbrook|title=Speaking For Myself: Film Maker Saltzman Also Restaurateur|newspaper=[[Watertown Daily Times]]|date=5 June 1969|page=9|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%20Disk3/Watertown%20Times/Watertown%20NY%20Daily%20Timers%201969%20Jun%20Grayscale.pdf/Watertown%20NY%20Daily%20Timers%201969%20Jun%20Grayscale%20-%200104.pdf}} Broccoli and Saltzman then decided to start production on ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' after [[Live and Let Die (film)|''Live and Let Die'']]. This was the final Bond film to be co-produced by Saltzman as his partnership with Broccoli was dissolved after the film's release. Saltzman sold his 50% stake in Eon Productions's parent company, Danjaq, LLC, to [[United Artists]] to alleviate his financial problems.{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=141-2}} The resulting legalities over the Bond property delayed production of the next Bond film, ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]'', for three years.{{cite video|title=Inside The Spy Who Loved Me|location=The Spy Who Loved Me Ultimate Edition, Disc 2|year=2000|format=NTSC, Widescreen, Closed-captioned|publisher=MGM/UA Home Video|medium=DVD|accessdate=27 March 2008}} The novel is mostly set in Jamaica, a location which had been already used in the earlier films, ''Dr. No'' and [[Live and Let Die (film)|''Live and Let Die'']]; ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' saw a change in location to put Bond in the Far East for the second time.{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=136}} After considering Beirut, where part of the film is set,{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=286}} Iran, where the [[location scouting]] was done but eventually discarded because of the [[Yom Kippur War]],{{cite video|people=Tom Mankewicz|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} and the [[Hạ Long Bay]] in Vietnam, the production team chose Thailand as a primary location, following a suggestion of production designer [[Peter Murton]] after he saw pictures of the [[Phang Nga Bay|Phuket bay]] in a magazine.{{cite video|title=Inside The Man with the Golden Gun|year=2000|format=NTSC, Widescreen, Closed-captioned|publisher=MGM/UA Home Video|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disc 2|medium=DVD | accessdate=27 March 2008}} Saltzman was happy with the choice of the Far East for the setting as he had always wanted to go on location in Thailand and Hong Kong.{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=211}} During the reconnaissance of locations in Hong Kong, Broccoli saw the wreckage of the former {{RMS|Queen Elizabeth}} and came up with the idea of using it as the base for MI6's Far East operations.{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=286}} ===Writing and themes=== [[Tom Mankiewicz]] wrote a first draft for the script in 1973, delivering a script that was a battle of wills between Bond and Scaramanga, who he saw as Bond's alter ego, "a super-villain of the stature of Bond himself."{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=215}} Tensions between Mankiewicz and Guy Hamilton{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=137}} and Mankiewicz's growing sense that he was "feeling really tapped out on Bond" led to the re-introduction of [[Richard Maibaum]] as the Bond screenwriter.{{sfn|Mankiewicz|Crane|2012|p=162}} Maibaum, who had worked on six Bond films previously, delivered his own draft based on Mankiewicz's work. Much of the plot involving Scaramanga being Bond's equal was sidelined in later drafts.{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=138}} For one of the two main aspects of the plot, the screenwriters used the [[1973 oil crisis|1973 energy crisis]] as a backdrop to the film,{{sfn|Black|2004|p=78}} allowing the [[MacGuffin]] of the "Solex agitator" to be introduced; Broccoli's stepson [[Michael G. Wilson]] researched solar power to create the Solex. While ''Live and Let Die'' had borrowed heavily from the [[blaxploitation]] genre,{{cite journal|last=Benshoff|first=Harry M|title=Blaxploitation Horror Films: Generic Reappropriation or Reinscription?|journal=Cinema Journal|date=Winter 2000|volume=39|issue=2|page=37|doi=10.1353/cj.2000.0001}} ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' borrowed from the [[Martial arts film|martial arts genre]]{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=140}} that was popular in the 1970s through films such as ''[[Fist of Fury]]'' (1972) and ''[[Enter the Dragon]]'' (1973).{{harvnb|Fu| Desser |2000|p=[http://catdir.loc.gov/catdir/samples/cam032/99045702.pdf 26]}} However, the use of the martial arts for a fight scene in the film "lapses into incredibility" when Lt Hip and his two nieces defeat an entire ''dojo''.{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=215}} ===Casting=== Originally, the role of Scaramanga was offered to [[Jack Palance]], but he turned the opportunity down.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=113}} Christopher Lee, who was eventually chosen to portray Scaramanga, was [[Ian Fleming]]'s step-cousin and Fleming had suggested Lee for the role of [[Julius No|Dr. Julius No]] in the 1962 series opener ''Dr. No''. Lee noted that Fleming was a forgetful man and by the time he mentioned this to Broccoli and Saltzman they had cast [[Joseph Wiseman]] in the part.{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/interviews/interview.asp?IID=844|title=Christopher Lee: The legendary actor on Scaramanga, Fleming and playing pure evil|work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|year=2009|accessdate=11 February 2009}} Due to filming on location in [[Bangkok]], his role in the film affected Lee's work the following year, as director [[Ken Russell]] was unable to sign Lee to play The Specialist in the 1975 film ''[[Tommy (1975 film)|Tommy]]'', a part eventually given to [[Jack Nicholson]].{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Frank|title=Tommy|url=http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/152705%7C0/Tommy.html|work=Turner Classic Movies|publisher=Turner Entertainment Networks, Inc|accessdate=10 August 2011}} Two Swedish models were cast as the [[Bond girl]]s, [[Britt Ekland]] and [[Maud Adams]]. Ekland had been interested in playing a Bond girl since she had seen ''Dr. No'', and contacted the producers about the main role of Mary Goodnight. Hamilton met Adams in New York, and cast her because "she was elegant and beautiful that it seemed to me she was the perfect Bond girl". When Ekland read the news that Adams had been cast for ''The Man with the Golden Gun'', she became upset, thinking Adams had been selected to play Goodnight. Broccoli then called Ekland to invite her for the main role, as after seeing her in a film, Broccoli thought Ekland's "generous looks" made her a good contrast to Adams. Hamilton decided to put Marc Lawrence, whom he had worked with on ''Diamonds Are Forever'', to play a gangster shot dead by Scaramanga at the start of the film, because he found it an interesting idea to "put sort of a Chicago gangster in the middle of Thailand".{{cite video|people=Guy Hamilton|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} ===Filming=== [[File:Seawise University wreck.jpg|thumb|1972: The wreck of the Seawise University, the former [[RMS Queen Elizabeth|RMS ''Queen Elizabeth'']], in Victoria Harbour, Hong Kong|alt= A half-sunken ship lies listing at 45 degrees]] Filming commenced on 6 November 1973 at the partly submerged wreck of the [[RMS Queen Elizabeth|RMS ''Queen Elizabeth'']], which acted as a top-secret MI6 base grounded in [[Victoria Harbour]] in Hong Kong.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=114}} The crew was small, and a stunt double was used for James Bond. Other Hong Kong locations included the [[Hong Kong Dragon Garden]] as the estate of [[Hai Fat]], which portrayed a location in [[Bangkok]].{{cite web|title=Public pleasure, private ownership?|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/hkedition/2010-07/20/content_11021386.htm|work=Christopher DeWolf|accessdate=7 July 2011}} The major part of [[principal photography]] started on 18 April 1974 in Thailand.{{cite journal|title=United Artists|journal=Film Bulletin|year=1974|volume=43-44|page=48}} Thai locations included [[Bangkok]], [[Thon Buri]], Phuket and the nearby [[Phang Nga Province]], on the islands of [[Khao Phing Kan|Ko Khao Phing Kan]] ({{lang-th|เกาะเขาพิงกัน}}) and [[Ko Tapu]] ({{lang-th|เกาะตะปู}}).{{sfn|Pfeiffer|Worrall|1998|p=102}}{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=286}} Scaramanga's hideout is on Ko Khao Phing Kan, and Ko Tapu is often now referred to as ''James Bond Island'' both by locals and in tourist guidebooks.{{cite video|title=Exotic Locations|year=2000|format=NTSC, Widescreen, Closed-captioned|publisher=MGM/UA Home Video|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disc 2|medium=DVD | accessdate=27 March 2008}} The scene during the boxing match used an actual [[Muay Thai]] fixture at the [[Lumpinee Boxing Stadium]].{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=286}} "[A] car chase [in Bangkok occurred] near a [canal or] [[khlong]] on Krung Kasem Road".[http://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/765132/blame-it-all-on-honey-and-her-white-bikini Blame it all on Honey and her white bikini] Production returned in late April to Hong Kong, and also to Macau, for that island is famous for [[Gambling in Macau|its casinos]], which Hong Kong lacks. Some scenes in Thailand had to be finished, and production had to move to studio work in [[Pinewood Studios]]; this included sets such as Scaramanga's solar energy plant and island interior. [[Academy Award]] winner [[Oswald Morris]] was hired to finish the job after cinematographer [[Ted Moore]] became ill.{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=135}} Morris was initially reluctant, as he did not like his previous experiences taking over other cinematographers' work, but accepted after dining with Broccoli.{{cite video|people=Oswald Morris|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} Production wrapped in Pinewood in August 1974.{{cite video|people=David Naylor|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} [[File:James Bond island.jpg|thumb|left|One of Scaramanga's Island's outcrops (high tide)|alt= A tall rocky outcrop sitting in the sea, another island is visible, dominating the background.]] One of the main stunts in the film consisted of stunt driver "Bumps" Willard (as James Bond) driving an [[AMC Hornet]] leaping a broken bridge and spinning around 360 degrees in mid-air about the longitudinal axis, doing an "aerial twist"; Willard successfully completed the jump on the first take.{{sfn|Pfeiffer|Worrall|1998|p=102}} The stunt was shown in slow motion, for the scene was otherwise too fast.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=119}} Composer [[John Barry (composer)|John Barry]] added a [[slide whistle]] sound effect over the stunt, which Broccoli kept in despite thinking that it "undercouped the stunt". Barry later regretted his decision, thinking the whistle "broke the golden rule" as the stunt was "for what it was all worth, a truly dangerous moment, ... true James Bond style".{{cite video|people=John Barry|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} The sound effect was described as "simply crass".{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=119}} The writer Jim Smith suggested that the stunt "brings into focus the lack of excitement in the rest of the film and is spoilt by the use of 'comedy' sound effects."{{sfn|Smith|2002|p=136}} Eon Productions had licensed the stunt, which had been designed by Raymond McHenry.{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=286}} It was initially conceived at [[Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory]] (CAL) in Buffalo, New York as a test for their vehicle simulation software. After development in simulation, ramps were built and the stunt was tested at CAL's proving ground.{{cite web |title=The Astro-Spiral Jump |publisher=McHenry Software|url=http://www.mchenrysoftware.com/mhvosm1.htm |accessdate=15 August 2011}} It toured as part of the All American Thrill Show as the Astro Spiral before it was picked up for the film. The television programme ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]'' attempted to repeat the stunt in June 2008, but failed.{{cite web|url=http://www.finalgear.com/shows/topgear/11/2/|title=Top Gear – Season 11, Episode 2 – 29 June 2008|work=Final Gear.com|accessdate=21 June 2009}} The scene where Scaramanga's [[AMC Matador|Matador]] flies was shot at [[Bovington Camp]], with a model inspired by an actual [[AVE Mizar|car plane]] prototype. Bond's duel with Scaramanga, which Mankewicz said was inspired by the climactic faceoff in ''[[Shane (film)|Shane]]'', was shortened as the producers felt it was causing pacing problems. The trailers featured some of the cut scenes. Hamilton adapted an idea of his involving Bond in [[Disneyland]] for Scaramanga's funhouse. The funhouse was designed to be a place where Scaramanga could get the upper hand by distracting the adversary with obstacles, and was described by Murton as a "melting pot of ideas" which made it "both a funhouse and a horror house".{{cite video|people=Peter Murton|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} While an actual wax figure of Roger Moore was used, Moore's stunt double Les Crawford was the cowboy figure, and Ray Marione played the Al Capone figure. The [[cant (architecture)|canted]] sets such as the funhouse and the ''Queen Elizabeth'' had inspiration from [[German Expressionism]] films such as ''[[The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari]]''. For Scaramanga's solar power plant, Hamilton used both the Pinewood set and a miniature projected by [[Derek Meddings]], often cutting between each other to show there was no discernible difference. The destruction of the facility was a combination of practical effects on the set and a destruction of the miniature. Meddings based the island blowing up on footage of the [[Battle of Monte Cassino]].{{cite video|people=Derek Meddings|title=The Man with the Golden Gun audio commentary|location=The Man with the Golden Gun Ultimate Edition, Disk 1|publisher=MGM Home Entertainment}} ====Golden Gun prop==== [[File:The Golden Gun.jpg|thumb|right|The Golden Gun.|alt= A golden gun is held by a hand.]] [[File:Golden Gun - International Spy Museum (14592496766).jpg|thumb|left|Scaramanga's Golden Gun]] Three Golden Gun props were made; a solid piece, one that could be fired with a cap and one that could be assembled and disassembled, although Christopher Lee said that the process "was extremely difficult." The gun was "one of the more memorable props in the Bond series"{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=114}} and consisted of an interlocking fountain pen (the barrel), cigarette lighter (the bullet chamber), cigarette case (the handle) and cufflink (the trigger) with the bullet secured in Scaramanga's belt buckle.{{sfn|Pfeiffer|Worrall|1998|p=103}} In the film, the gun was designed to accept a single 4.2-millimetre, 23-[[Carat (purity)|carat]] gold bullet produced by Lazar, a gunsmith in Macau who specialized in custom weapons and ammunition.{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=235}} The Golden Gun ranked sixth in a 2008 [[20th Century Fox]] poll of the most popular film weapons, which surveyed approximately 2,000 film fans.{{cite news | first = Sophie |last=Borland | title = Lightsabre wins the battle of movie weapons |work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 21 January 2008 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1576154/Lightsabre-wins-the-battle-of-movie-weapons.html | accessdate=17 June 2015}} On 10 October 2008, it was discovered that one of the golden guns used in the film, which is estimated to be worth around £80,000, was missing (suspected stolen) from [[Elstree Studios|Elstree Props]], a company based at Hertfordshire studios.{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/3174163/James-Bond-golden-gun-stolen-from-Elstree-Studios.html | title=James Bond golden gun stolen from Elstree Studios |work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Stephen |last=Adams | accessdate=23 June 2009| location=London | date=10 October 2008}} ===Music=== {{Main|The Man with the Golden Gun (soundtrack)}} The theme tune to ''The Man with the Golden Gun'', released in 1974, was performed by Scottish singer [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]] and composed by [[John Barry (composer)|John Barry]]. Tony Bramwell, who worked for Harry Saltzman's music publishing company Hilary Music, wanted [[Elton John]] or [[Cat Stevens]] to sing the title song. However, by this time the producers were taking turns producing the films; Albert Broccoli—whose turn it was to produce—rejected Bramwell's suggestions. The lyrics to the Lulu song were written by [[Don Black (lyricist)|Don Black]] and have been described variously as "ludicrous",{{sfn|Pfeiffer|Worrall|1998|p=103}} "inane"{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=215}} and "one long stream of smut", because of their [[Innuendo|sexual innuendo]].{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=92}} Bramwell subsequently dismissed the Barry-Lulu tune as "mundane".{{sfn|Bramwell|Kingsland|2006|p=368}} [[Alice Cooper]] wrote a song titled "Man with the Golden Gun" to be used by the producers of the film, but they opted for Lulu's song instead. Cooper released his song in his album ''[[Muscle of Love]]''.{{sfn|Greene|1974|p=40}} Barry had only three weeks to score ''The Man with the Golden Gun''{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=287}} and the theme tune and score are generally considered by critics to be among the weakest of Barry's contributions to the series, an opinion shared by Barry himself: "It's the one I hate most ... it just never happened for me."{{cite video | people =Barry, John (interviewee) |year=2006 | title =James Bond's Greatest Hits | medium =Television | location =UK | publisher =North One Television}} ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' was also the first to drop the distinctive plucked guitar from the [[James Bond Theme|theme]] heard over the [[Gun barrel sequence (James Bond)|gun barrel opening]]. A sample from one of the songs, "Hip's Trip", was used by [[The Prodigy]] in the "Mindfields" track on the album ''[[The Fat of the Land]]''.[http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/movies/tmwtgg_music.php3?t=tmwtgg&s=tmwtgg Music – The Man With The Golden Gun]. [[Mi6-HQ.com]]. Retrieved 15 August 2011. ==Release and reception== [[File:James Bond 007 pistol toy.jpg|thumb|right|210px|The James Bond 007 pistol, produced by [[Lone Star Toys]].|alt=A toy pistol, in gold, with a black silencer: the item is still in a box]] ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' was premiered at the [[Odeon Leicester Square]] in London on {{nowrap|19 December 1974}},{{cite news|last=Hickey|first=William|title=Shaking on it – one man to another|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|date=20 December 1974}} with general release in the United Kingdom the same day. The film was made with an estimated budget of $7 million; despite initial good returns from the box office,{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=116}} ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' grossed a total of $97.6 million at the worldwide box office,{{cite web|title=The Man with the Golden Gun|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1974/0MWGG.php|work=The Numbers|publisher=Nash Information Services, LLC.|accessdate=8 August 2011}} with $21 million earned in the USA, making it the fourth lowest-grossing Bond film in the series.{{cite web|title=Box Office History for James Bond Movies|url=http://the-numbers.com/movies/series/JamesBond.php|work=The Numbers|publisher=Nash Information Services, LLC.|accessdate=8 August 2011}} The promotion of the film had "one of the more anaemic advertising campaigns of the series"{{sfn|Pfeiffer|Worrall|1998|p=103}} and there were few products available, apart from the soundtrack and paperback book, although [[Lone Star Toys]] produced a "James Bond 007 pistol" in gold; this differed from the weapon used by Scaramanga in the film as it was little more than a [[Walther P38]] with a silencer fitted.{{Cite journal|journal=Collectors' Gazette|date=July 2007|issue=280|pages=12, 13|title=Lone Star's 'Top Ten' Diecast guns|first=Geoffrey|last=Ambridge|url=http://lonestarproductsltduk.blogspot.com/2007/06/collectors-gazette-july-07-issue-lone.html}} ===Contemporary reviews=== ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' met with mixed reviews upon its release. [[Derek Malcolm]] in ''[[The Guardian]]'' savaged the film, saying that "the script is the limpest of the lot and ... Roger Moore as 007 is the last man on earth to make it sound better than it is."{{cite news|last=Malcolm|first=Derek|title=Rebel without a pause|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=19 December 1974}} There was some praise from Malcolm, although it was muted, saying that "Christopher Lee ... makes a goodish villain and Britt Ekland a passable Mary Goodnight ... Up to scratch in production values ... the film is otherwise merely a potboiler. Maybe enough's enough." Tom Milne, writing in ''[[The Observer]]'', was even more caustic, writing that "This series, which has been scraping the bottom of the barrel for some time, is now through the bottom ... with depressing borrowings from Hong Kong kung fu movies, not to mention even more depressing echoes of the '[[Carry On (franchise)|Carry On]]' smut."{{cite news|last=Milne|first=Tom|title=From Badlands to Bond|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|date=22 December 1974}} He summed up the film by saying it was "sadly lacking in wit or imagination." [[David Robinson (film critic)|David Robinson]], the film critic at ''[[The Times]]'', dismissed the film and Moore's performance, saying that Moore was "substituting non-acting for Connery's throwaway", while Britt Ekland was "his beautiful, idiot side-kick ... the least appealing of the Bond heroines."{{cite news|last=Robinson|first=David|title=A trip back to the forest of Dean|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=20 December 1974}} Robinson was equally damning of the changes in the production crew, observing that Ken Adam, an "attraction of the early Bond films," had been "replaced by decorators of competence but little of his flair." The writers "get progressively more naive in their creation of a suburban dream of epicureanism and adventure." Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Nora Sayre considered the film to suffer from "poverty of invention and excitement", criticising the writing and Moore's performance and finding Villechaize and Lee as the only positive points for their "sinister vitality that cuts through the narrative dough."{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9401E6D91E31EF34BC4152DFB467838F669EDE|title=Movie Review – The Man with the Golden Gun – Film: James Bond and Energy Crisis|work=The New York Times|first=Nora|last=Sayre|date=19 December 1974|accessdate=13 August 2011}} The ''[[Sunday Mirror]]'' critic observed that ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' "isn't the best Bond ever" but found it "remarkable that Messrs. Saltzman and Broccoli can still produce such slick and inventive entertainment". Arthur Thirkwell, writing in the ''Sunday Mirror''{{'}}s sister paper, the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' concentrated more on lead actor Roger Moore than the film itself: "What Sean Connery used to achieve with a touch of sardonic sadism, Roger Moore conveys with roguish schoolboy charm and the odd, dry quip."{{cite news|last=Thirkwell|first=Arthur|title=It's Bond, shaky – but still stirring|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=18 December 1974}} Thirkwell also said that Moore "manages to make even this reduced-voltage Bond a character with plenty of sparkle." Judith Crist of ''[[New York Magazine]]'' gave a positive review, saying "the scenery's grand, the lines nice and the gadgetry entertaining", also describing the production as a film that "capture[s] the free-wheeling, whooshing non-sense of early Fleming's fairy tale for grown-ups orientation".{{cite journal|last=Crist |first=Judith|title=Movies – All in the Family|journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=23 December 1974}} [[Jay Cocks]], writing in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', focused on gadgets such as Scaramanga's flying car, as what is wrong with both ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' and the more recent films in the Bond series, calling them "Overtricky, uninspired, these exercises show the strain of stretching fantasy well past wit."{{cite news|last=Cocks|first=Jay|title=Cinema: Water Pistols|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,917047,00.html|accessdate=9 August 2011|newspaper= [[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=13 January 1975}} Cocks also criticised the actors, saying that Moore "lacks all Connery's strengths and has several deep deficiencies", while Lee was "an unusually unimpressive villain". ===Reflective reviews=== Opinion on ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' has for the most part remained the same as it was in 1974 and as of November 2015, the film holds a 45% rating from [[Rotten Tomatoes]] (although these contain contemporary reviews),{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/man_with_the_golden_gun/ | title=The Man with the Golden Gun | work= Rotten Tomatoes | accessdate=24 September 2007}} while Ian Freer of ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' found the film "an entertaining 007 adventure, something that tonally, if not qualitatively, could happily sit within the Connery era."{{cite web | url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=134602 | title=The Man with the Golden Gun | work=Empire|first=Ian|last=Freer|date=13 October 2008 | accessdate=13 August 2011}} ''[[IGN]]'' chose ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' as the worst Bond film, claiming it "has a great concept ... but the execution is sloppy and silly",{{cite web|url=http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/746/746573p1.html|title=James Bond's Top 20|publisher=IGN|date=17 November 2006|accessdate=21 December 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305105945/http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/746/746573p1.html|archivedate=5 March 2009|df=dmy-all}} and ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' chose it as the fourth worst, saying that the "plot is almost as puny as the sidekick".{{cite web | url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20431259_1560083,00.html |first1=Benjamin |last1=Svetkey |first2=Joshua |last2=Rich| title=James Bond: Ranking 21 films |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=14 November 2008 | accessdate=21 June 2009}} On the other hand, Norman Wilner of [[MSN]] chose it as the tenth best, with much praise for Christopher Lee's performance.{{cite web|url=http://movies.sympatico.msn.ca/features/ArticleNormanWilner.aspx?cp-documentid=436189|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119210839/http://movies.sympatico.msn.ca/features/ArticleNormanWilner.aspx?cp-documentid=436189|archivedate=19 January 2008|title=Rating the Spy Game|publisher=MSN|author=Norman Wilner|accessdate=4 March 2008}} Some critics saw the film as uninspired, tired and boring.{{cite web|url=http://preview.reelviews.net/movies/m/man_golden.html |first=James |last=Berardinelli |authorlink=James Berardinelli |title=The Man with the Golden Gun|publisher=[[ReelViews]]|year=1996|accessdate=13 August 2011}} Roger Moore was also criticised for playing Bond against type, in a style more reminiscent of Sean Connery, although Lee's performance received acclaim. [[Danny Peary]] wrote that ''The Man with the Golden Gun'' "lacks invention ... is one of the least interesting Bond films" and "a very laboured movie, with Bond a stiff bore, Adams and Britt Ekland uninspired leading ladies".{{sfn|Peary|1986|p=264}} Peary believes that the shootout between Bond and Scaramanga in the funhouse "is the one good scene in the movie, and even it has an unsatisfying finish" and also bemoaned the presence of Clifton James, "unfortunately reprising his unfunny redneck sheriff from ''Live and Let Die.''"{{sfn|Peary|1986|p=264}} Chris Nashawaty of ''Entertainment Weekly'' argues that Scaramanga is the best villain of the Roger Moore James Bond films,{{cite journal|last=Nashawaty|first=Chris|title=Moore ... and Sometimes Less|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=12 December 2008|issue=1025|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20244432,00.html|accessdate=9 August 2011}} while listing Mary Goodnight among the worst Bond girls, saying that "Ekland may have had one of the series' best bikinis, but her dopey, doltish portrayal was a turnoff as much to filmgoers as to fans of Ian Fleming's novels".{{cite web|title=6. Mary Goodnight (Britt Ekland)|date= 10 November 2006|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1557936,00.html |last=Rich |first=Joshua|work=10 worst Bond girls|accessdate=11 August 2011}} ''The Times'' put Scaramanga as the fifth best Bond villain in their list,{{cite news|last=Plant|first=Brendan|title=Top 10 Bond villains|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/specials/for_your_eyes_only/article3660946.ece|accessdate=11 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=1 April 2008}} and Ekland was the third in their list of the top 10 most fashionable Bond girls.{{cite news|last=Copping|first=Nicola|title=Top 10 most fashionable Bond girls|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/specials/for_your_eyes_only/article3628924.ece|accessdate=11 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=1 April 2008}} ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' listed Goodnight at fourth in their Top Bond Babes list, saying that "Agent Goodnight is the clumsiest spy alive. But who cares as long as she's using her perfect bikini bottom to muck things up?"{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/amg/girls/girls-of-maxim/44096/top-bond-babes.html|title=The Top Bond Babes|work=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]|accessdate=14 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110917173055/http://www.maxim.com/amg/girls/girls-of-maxim/44096/top-bond-babes.html|archivedate=17 September 2011|df=dmy-all}} ==See also== * [[List of James Bond henchmen in The Man with the Golden Gun|List of henchmen in ''The Man with the Golden Gun'']] * [[Outline of James Bond]] {{Portalbar|James Bond|1970s|Film}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Sources== {{Refbegin|colwidth=40em}} * {{Cite book |last1=Barnes |first1=Alan |last2=Hearn |first2=Marcus |year=2001 |title=Kiss Kiss Bang! Bang!: the Unofficial James Bond Film Companion|publisher=[[Batsford Books]]|isbn=978-0-7134-8182-2|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book |last=Benson |first=Raymond |title=The James Bond Bedside Companion |year=1988 |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Boxtree Ltd]] |location=London |isbn=1-85283-234-7 |ref=harv}} * {{Cite book |last=Black |first=Jeremy |title= Britain Since the Seventies: Politics and Society in the Consumer Age |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=cM30JeLgjQUC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2004 |publisher=Biddles Ltd |location=Guilford |isbn= 978-1-86189-201-0 |ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|last=Black|first=Jeremy|title=The Politics of James Bond: from Fleming's Novel to the Big Screen|year=2005|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|isbn=978-0-8032-6240-9|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|last1=Bramwell|first1=Tony|last2=Kingsland|first2=Rosemary|title=Magical Mystery Tours: My Life with the Beatles|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]]|year=2006|edition=reprint|isbn=978-0-312-33044-6|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|last=Broccoli|first=Albert R|title=When the Snow Melts|year=1998|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Boxtree Ltd]]|location=London|isbn=978-0-7522-1162-6 |ref=harv}} * {{Cite book |last1= Cork |first1= John|last2= Stutz |first2=Collin |title=James Bond Encyclopedia|year=2007 |publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]] The ''' World English-Language Scrabble Players' Association ''' ('''WESPA''') is the overarching global body for English-language national [[Scrabble]] associations and similar entities.
== Formation ==
WESPA was formed in the course of a players' meeting at the [[World Scrabble Championship 2003|2003 World Scrabble Championship]] in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and formally constituted on 17 November 2005 at its first Biennial General Meeting held in [[World Scrabble Championship 2005|London]]. BGMs are now held at each [[World Scrabble Championship]] (taking place every odd year), and there are currently 24 member organisations.
WESPA was created to represent the interests of international Scrabble competitors and national bodies worldwide. Its main functions are to promote global recognition of Scrabble as a serious competitive activity; to provide for the benefit of members in pursuing the game; to further the best interests of Scrabble and international tournament players; to represent such players in dealings with other bodies, including the trademark owners of the game; to promulgate and encourage international convergence towards common standards and norms (including international rules, word lists and ratings); to organise global competitions and events; to publish relevant material; and to maintain a website for the benefit of the game and its players.
The trademark for Scrabble is owned by [[Hasbro]] in North America and [[Mattel]] in the rest of the world.
Achievements to date have included the preparation of a set of international rules, the publication of a WESPA-endorsed word list which is valid for international tournament play, and the promulgation of international Scrabble ratings.
== Rules ==
Following a six-month worldwide consultation process, the first version of WESPA's rules for global Scrabble was released in August 2009. The rules were based on key elements of existing rules that were in force in various national associations, which were synthesised to create global best practice. Following feedback from their use in various international tournaments, extensive reviews took place prior to the issue of version two in November 2010, which was used at the [[World Scrabble Championship 2011|2011 World Scrabble Championship]] in Warsaw, Poland, and other international events such as the Causeway Challenge.<ref>http://www.causewayscrabble.com/</ref> Version three was released in 2015.
A number of national associations have adopted WESPA rules for domestic use, including the [[Association of British Scrabble Players]].
== Word list ==
The word source currently in use for international play, known as [[Collins Scrabble Words]] or CSW (formerly Official Scrabble Words or OSW) is not derived from a single dictionary, but combines three components: [[Collins English Dictionary|Collins]] (7th edition, 2005), [[Chambers Dictionary|Chambers]] (1998 edition) and [[Official Tournament and Club Word List|TWL]], the current Northern American wordlist. TWL (Tournament Word List) is a subset of CSW, but is itself drawn from a range of sources, mostly different editions of [[Webster's Dictionary|Webster's]]. North American tournaments generally use TWL alone for domestic play, but all tournaments under the auspices of WESPA must use CSW.
The current word list (CSW15) came into force internationally on 1 September 2015, including updates from the most recent editions of original OSW sources as well as eliminating some inconsistencies in previous editions. CSW15 contains over 275,000 words in total (up to the theoretical maximum fifteen letters in length), of which around 119,000 are up to eight letters in length. By contrast, TWL holds approximately two thirds as many words in total. CSW is therefore substantially larger than TWL and has a more international flavour, including a number of local or dialect words from around the world.
== Ratings ==
International Scrabble ratings have been maintained since their inception by Bob Jackman in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]], using a variant of the Australian ratings calculation system. All tournaments played to WESPA rules are able to be rated within the system, and regular updates are posted on the WESPA website. The first rated tournament in the system was the [[World Scrabble Championship 1993|1993 World Scrabble Championship]], which was held in New York.
== Tournaments ==
WESPA has established the criteria for running international Scrabble tournaments, and it is now mandatory for WESPA rules and the WESPA word list to be used. Tournament organisers are also required to pay a ratings levy on a fee per player basis, in order for the tournament to qualify for international rating.
The tournament committee oversees the calendar of international Scrabble events, and has also liaised with Mattel on a number of issues relating to the World Scrabble Championship (WSC), including the number of games to be played and the format of the finals. Furthermore, a country's allocated number of representatives may fluctuate for each WSC depending on the team performance in the previous event, and WESPA has ratified the formula<ref>http://www.wscgames.com/2011/history.html</ref> for changes to team allocations. In short, after each event the participating countries are ranked according to the average individual finishing rank of their players; teams falling in the top half may be entitled to gain a player for next time, while teams in the bottom half may lose a player.
Following the establishment of Mind Sports International, the title '[[World Scrabble Championship]]' was claimed by that entity for official world titles (sanctioned by Mattel under licence). WESPA has undertaken to host biennial world events from 2015 onwards using the old WSC format, with teams qualifying from national organisations. The WESPA Championship 2015 was hosted in Perth, Australia, and the 2017 edition took place in Nairobi, Kenya.
== Youth Scrabble ==
The [[World Youth Scrabble Championships]], renamed WESPA Youth Cup for 2017 further to a naming issue with Mindsports Academy, have been organised annually since 2006 under the aegis of WESPA for players under 18 on qualification date. The Youth committee has also been active in promoting the game among young players worldwide, including training workshops held in various locations.
== Committee ==
The WESPA committee is made up of nominees representing member nations, and the current Chair is Elie Dangoor (UK). Various subcommittees are charged with matters such as promotions and communications, ratings and tournaments, rules, dictionary and youth.
The first Chair of WESPA was [[Allan Simmons]] (UK) who led the organisation from inception through to 2008. He was succeeded by [[Bahrain]]-based Roy Kietzmann, who died in 2009 prior to the appointment of Elie Dangoor.
== Other federations ==
WESPA has committee links with the two other major world Scrabble federations, FISF (Fédération Internationale de Scrabble Francophone)<ref>http://www.fisf.net</ref> and FISE (Federación Internacional de Scrabble en Español).<ref>http://www.fisescrabble.org</ref>
== Mailing list ==
The world-scrabble mailing list<ref>http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/world-scrabble/</ref> discusses international Scrabble matters and WESPA issues.
